column2: Postgraduate Scholarships"^"Widespread beliefs and opinions held by a community about a topic is known as "community sentiment". It is critical to understand community sentiment about public health measures as it will affect compliance. Artificial intelligence can be used to analyse sentences
column3: phrases and words in open-source media and social media to measure community sentiment. This can be done in many languages and locations in real time to inform health policy. It can be adapted to any language
column4: area or health issue."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022364^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022364"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Comparing the Efficacy and Acceptability of Genomic Testing and Skin Biopsy in Diagnosing Monogenic Skin Disease
column2: Postgraduate Scholarships"^"A skin biopsy is currently the first-line diagnostic-investigation for individuals with suspected genetic skin diseases. It would be valuable to determine whether this invasive procedure could be replaced with a saliva sample and genomic testing. This proposal aims to measure the cost-effectiveness
column3: diagnostic yield and clinical impact of these test modalities
column4: in addition to examining the attitudes of relevant stakeholders – including patients
column5: families and clinicians."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022368^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022368"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Assessing the cardiac arrhythmia profile of cancer therapeutics
column2: Postgraduate Scholarships"^"Heart rhythm disorders or arrhythmias can result from cancer treatment. A lab-based study will assess the mechanisms of cancer-treatment induced long QT syndrome
column3: which can result in fatal arrhythmias. A clinical study will recruit patients treated with medications that use the immune system to fight cancer. A side effect of these medications includes heart inflammation and arrhythmias. This study will develop methods to diagnose heart inflammation and markers that indicate arrhythmia risk."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022377^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022377"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Critical evaluation of the diagnostic utility of whole genome and transcriptome sequencing and the training of physicians in the deployment of frontier diagnostic technologies in healthcare
column2: Postgraduate Scholarships"^"Rare diseases are largely uncommon but collectively
column3: they result in significant morbidity. Most rare disease is genetic in origin and the majority of children with rare disease remain undiagnosed following genetic testing. This project focuses on increasing diagnoses in children with rare disease through novel testing strategies such as combined genome and RNA sequencing
column4: as well as improving their overall care by upskilling and improving genomic literacy in medical specialists."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022380^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022380"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Prescription Drug Monitoring Program in New South Wales: A mixed methods study of implementation processes
column2: stakeholder experiences
column3: and program impact
column4: Postgraduate Scholarships"^"Harm from high-risk prescription medicines including opioids is a public health concern. Prescription Drug Monitoring Programs (PDMP) are electronic systems that monitor these high-risk medicines and warn health care professionals when a patient is at risk. This research project will investigate how the NSW PDMP (SafeScript NSW) was implemented and will explore health care providers' and consumers' experiences and perceptions of the new PDMP tool in NSW."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022387^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022387"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Functional connectivity-guided transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) treatment for young people with major depression
column2: Postgraduate Scholarships"^"Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) is a Medicare-subsidised treatment for depression that normalises brain changes. However
column3: neuroimaging studies of adolescent depression has generated inconsistent results
column4: hindering the development of better TMS treatment for this age group. This study aims to establish a robust understanding of the neurobiology underlying adolescent depression and integrate this knowledge to improve TMS treatment efficacy for young people suffering from major depression."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022391^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022391"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Evidence Supporting Strategies for Coronary Artery Revascularisation
column2: Postgraduate Scholarships"^"My PhD project examines the quality and safety of treatments for coronary artery disease (CAD) and seeks to demonstrates the outcomes from these in various patient groups including in women and indigenous populations. New techniques in Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery (CABG) have been refined
column3: but the comparisons between these and stenting is limited. With the help of artificial intelligence and medical machine learning
column4: this project will provide novel data to improve patient survival globally."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022415^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022415"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Predicting and preventing sepsis in patients with haematological malignancy
column2: Postgraduate Scholarships"^"Sepsis is overwhelming reaction to severe infection. Patients with haematological malignancy (blood cancers) have reduced immunity to infection and many develop sepsis. The treatments available for blood cancers have improved in recent years
column3: but the risk of dying from sepsis is still high. My research program will help understand which patients are at the highest risk of sepsis
column4: and whether we can prevent sepsis with immunoglobulin (antibody) treatment or improved hospital hygiene strategies."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022417^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022417"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Heart Failure Prevention in Cancer Survivors by Recognition and Treatment of Subclinical Disease
column2: Postgraduate Scholarships"^"Cancer survivors have an increased risk of heart failure (HF) due to chemotherapy toxicity & shared risks between cancer & heart disease. Subclinical heart failure (SBHF) are changes in echocardiography occurring prior to symptoms
column3: allowing initiation of cardioprotective therapies (medications
column4: exercise) - reducing the risk of overt HF. We aim to detect SBHF in cancer survivors & evaluate impact of early cardioprotection. We expect this will improve functional capacity & delay/prevent overt HF."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022424^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022424"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Detection of autoantibodies using novel bioluminescent systems
column2: Postgraduate Scholarships"^"This research aims to develop new and improved laboratory tests to identify and measure antibodies and other markers in the bloodstream that are associated with autoimmune diseases
column3: including a number of different neurological conditions. More accurate detection of these markers is important to allow early diagnosis and treatment of autoimmune diseases
column4: and prevent their complications including long term disability."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022453^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022453"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Optimising Biologics in Inflammatory Bowel Disease
column2: Postgraduate Scholarships"^"There is no cure for inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)
column3: & the underpinning mechanisms involved in disease development are poorly understood. Patients often progress on first line treatment and need ‘biologic’ therapy to control their disease
column4: thereby keeping them healthy and improving their quality of life. My research aims to evaluate the clinical and cellular issues of IBD
column5: and personalise treatments based on the individual which will help decide treatment strategies to keep patients healthy."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022454^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022454"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Novel policy approaches to reduce the supply and availability of tobacco products
column2: Postgraduate Scholarships"^"This research aims to reduce tobacco smoking in Australia. Tobacco is widely available to purchase
column3: making it difficult for smokers to quit and easy for young people to start. I will find new options for reducing availability of tobacco by looking at models used in other countries for harmful products. I will develop new policy options for reducing tobacco supply and gain feedback from the public and other stakeholders
column4: which I will use to make policy recommendations."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022463^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022463"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeted and stem cell therapeutics for Cystic Fibrosis sinus disease
column2: Postgraduate Scholarships"^"Despite advances in treatment for Cystic Fibrosis
column3: (CF) there is currently no cure. The sinonasal airway provides valuable insights into the lower airway. The impact of modulators on the sinonasal airway before and after treatment in the paediatric CF population will be studied. A rabbit sinus model will be developed to further define the essential preclinical steps to deliver rabbits own corrected airway stem-cells to renew the damaged cells within the sinus and lung."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022470^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022470"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Investigating Novel Prevention and Treatment Strategies for for Gonococcal Control
column2: Postgraduate Scholarships"^"Gonorrhoea infection can lead to long term health problems including infertility. Cases of gonorrhoea continue to increase and antibiotic-resistant strains have been reported
column3: prompting WHO to declare an urgent need for new strategies to prevent the spread of untreatable gonorrhoea. My study focuses on this priority by generating new knowledge towards alternative strategies for gonococcal disease control including vaccine development and non-antibiotic strategies to treat gonorrhoea."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022471^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022471"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Human amnion epithelial cell derived novel therapeutics in inflammatory bowel disease
column2: Postgraduate Scholarships"^"We will examine the potential therapeutic properties of extracellular vesicles
column3: particles that carry messages between cells
column4: that can be harvested from human amnion epithelial cells
column5: a type of stem cell found in the amniotic membrane. We will then apply this as a treatment for perianal fistulising Crohn’s disease
column6: a difficult to manage type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) with a higher risk of poor outcomes. Our goal is to establish a novel new therapy for patients suffering with IBD."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022495^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022495"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Towards treatment of intellectual disability caused by errors in the chromatin machinery
column2: Postgraduate Scholarships"^"Disorders that influence the expression of genes may be influenced by the metabolic environment in the cell. This research aims to characterise the metabolic environment and to see if there may be potential treatments for these metabolic disorders by supplementing deficient nutrients/substrates. In addition
column3: we would be interested in characterising the biomarkers of these conditions to see if there are other chemicals that might be helpful to track treatment for these conditions."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022510^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022510"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Vaccine Champions and Vaccine Communication program
column2: Postgraduate Scholarships"^"The Vaccine Champions and Vaccine Communication (VCVC) program aims to increase the number of people getting the COVID-19 vaccine and to build confidence in vaccines by empowering healthcare providers
column3: community
column4: faith
column5: and industry leaders to become vaccine “champions” within their communities
column6: in three Western Pacific countries. Champions will run vaccine information sessions in the community
column7: addressing concerns and misconceptions. This research will assess the impact of the VCVC program."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022517^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022517"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Novel bacteria as a therapy for inflammatory bowel disease
column2: Postgraduate Scholarships"^"Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is an incurable disease
column3: affecting 1 in 200 Australians and is thought to be related to an imbalance between protective and harmful bacteria in our gut. Despite years of research
column4: a large proportion of these bacteria remain unknown or poorly understood. Our team has succeeded in identifying a vast number of new species. I will use novel techniques to further understand the relationship between these bacteria and IBD
column5: and lead the development of a new treatment."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022530^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022530"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Application of novel personalised medicine tools to understand treatment mechanisms in Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia
column2: Postgraduate Scholarships"^"Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia (PCD) is a rare genetic condition mostly affecting the respiratory tract
column3: causing recurrent respiratory infections eventually leading to scarred and dilated airways. Research on the best treatment for patients with PCD is scarce. This study will use medical imaging and mini airway organs created in a lab from cells collected from the nose of PCD patients to measure the impact of treatments in patients with PCD."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022548^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022548"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Better Vision for Patients with Ocular Toxoplasmosis
column2: Postgraduate Scholarships"^"Toxoplasma gondii is a parasite that causes the eye disease called ocular toxoplasmosis. There are no medications that can rid the body of the parasite
column3: and there is no vaccine that prevents an infection. The goal of my research is to improve vision outcomes in patients with ocular toxoplasmosis. I will investigate a new treatment that targets inflammatory molecules to protect the eye tissues
column4: and I will develop clinical algorithms to identify patients who would benefit most from treatment."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022557^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022557"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Designing Bayesian clinical trials to enhance clinician- and consumer-directed decision-making
column2: Postgraduate Scholarships"^"Clinical trials are designed to answer scientific research questions. It is therefore hard for clinicians and consumers to use the trial results for their own decision-making. This is because the research question does not consider their individual preferences and so may not be helpful to them. To change this
column3: we need a better way to evaluate and report trial results to make decision-making easier. This project will use advanced statistics to design better clinical trials."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018592^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018592"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Reducing the impact of radiation on the heart for cancer and cardiac disease patients
column2: Synergy Grants"^"This program will develop the integrated technology and perform datamining
column3: animal and human studies to provide a comprehensive understanding on the response of substructures in the heart to radiation. This work will benefits patients receiving radiation therapy for cancer treatments where we aim to minimise cardiac complications post treatment. Our work will also benefit patients with advanced ventricular tachycardia where radiation is being used to reduce the number of painful ICD shocks."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018642^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018642"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Improving outcomes for high-risk child and adolescent cancer: from discovery to individualised treatment within a consumer partnership
column2: Synergy Grants"^"Cancer is the commonest disease causing death in children. New anticancer drugs are developed against one adult cancer gene target. Anticancer drugs work best in combination to overcome resistance. Our network of scientists and doctors have developed a diagnostic platform to better match the drug to the gene target for high risk child cancer. We will develop effective child cancer-specific combination therapy
column3: accurate diagnostics for resistance and integrate consumers in the research pathway."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018654^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018654"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Accelerating to zero: targeting roadblocks to achieve malaria elimination
column2: Synergy Grants"^"This Synergy Grant addresses major knowledge and translation gaps that are key roadblocks to achieving malaria elimination. The new knowledge
column3: tools
column4: and strategies developed in this program through innovative and targeted research is responsive to global priorities and will directly inform policy and health practices
column5: as well as driving future innovation."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018668^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018668"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Synergise
column2: Integrate and Enhance Sleep Research to Transform Brain Ageing (SIESTA)
column3: Synergy Grants"^"Modifiable risk factors account for up to 40% of dementia risk
column4: and sleep disturbance (SD) has emerged as a viable new target. This project will assess SD
column5: cognitive decline and dementia pathology using methods including novel blood-based biomarkers. This project will also develop scalable digital health solutions addressing SD
column6: and assess the impact of interventions on SD and dementia biomarkers
column7: in order to translate findings into clinical practice and substantially reduce dementia risk."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018970^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018970"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Improving Aboriginal health by understanding the influence of early life environments and contacts with health and social service systems over time and across generations
column2: Synergy Grants"^"This project is a partnership between researchers
column3: the Aboriginal community and government to provide evidence for policy and practice addressing high priority health conditions for Aboriginal children and families. It will use a longitudinal linked dataset based on a population representative sample of Aboriginal children and their families (the 2000/02 Western Australian Aboriginal Child Health Survey) and government data across health
column4: education
column5: child protection
column6: and justice domains."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019056^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019056"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Advancing the treatment of brain cancer in children
column2: Synergy Grants"^"Brain cancers are the number one cause of cancer related death in children. Treatment for this group of cancers is aggressive and includes chemotherapy
column3: surgery and radiotherapy. This research will develop innovative nano-sized drug carriers to deliver therapies and imaging agents to detect and kill brain tumours. If successful
column4: this work has the potential to markedly change treatment strategies to improve the survival of paediatric brain cancer patients."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019247^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019247"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"How can health districts and networks cultivate anti-racist hospitals?
column2: Synergy Grants"^"The aim of this research is to enable local health networks and districts in Australia to tackle systemic racism in hospitals. Specifically
column3: this research will use tools and frameworks to improve quality of hospital care and reduce health inequities for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. This work will be undertaken by a team of researchers with expertise and skills across public health
column4: social science and Indigenous ways of working."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019251^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019251"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Using complex models of human trophoblast to study placental biology and disease
column2: Synergy Grants"^"In this synergy grant
column3: a multidisciplinary team of researchers in stem cell biology
column4: placenta
column5: epigenetics
column6: embryonic implantation and computational science will work together to study the placenta using different artificial models. This will allow us to understand how early placenta is formed in humans
column7: how it interacts with the cells of the uterus of the mother and unveil the genetic and toxicity insults that contribute to problems in pregnancy."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019252^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019252"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The Interdisciplinary Tobacco Endgame Research Network (INTER-Net)
column2: Synergy Grants"^"Tobacco smoking remains the leading preventable cause of early death and disease globally. Australia has been a global leader in implementing policies that have reduced smoking to one of the lowest rates in the world. This multidisciplinary research program will examine promising new approaches to minimising smoking in Australia using methods from epidemiology and applied statistics
column3: health policy
column4: law
column5: the social sciences
column6: and economics."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019260^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019260"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Rhythms and blues: Personalising care for body clock dysfunction in mood disorders
column2: Synergy Grants"^"This project aims to improve our knowledge about how problems with “body clocks” might lead to mood disorders like depression and bipolar disorder. We expect this research will (1) lead to better ways to measure body clock function
column3: (2) reveal more clearly how body clocks are affected in mood disorders
column4: (3) help clinicians predict whose mood disorder will persist or get worse over time
column5: and (4) guide clinicians about what treatments can help improve people’s body clocks and mental health."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2024704^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2024704"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"IRIISS - 2022
column2: Independent Research Institutes Infrastructure Support Scheme (IRIISS)"^"Not Applicable"^""^""^""^

column2: Independent Research Institutes Infrastructure Support Scheme (IRIISS)"^"Not Applicable"^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2024693^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2024693"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"IRIISS - 2022

column2: Independent Research Institutes Infrastructure Support Scheme (IRIISS)"^"Not Applicable"^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2016736^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2016736"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Dental health
column2: mental health and economic productivity; a child longitudinal study
column3: Partnership Projects"^"Working with partners across each State and Territory to ensure local tailoring and national implementation
column4: we will undertake NCOHS-2 – oral epidemiological examinations and questionnaire data on approximately 32
column5: 000 Australian children aged 5 to 14 years – then compare against NCOHS-1 data to test
column6: model
column7: evaluate and disseminate evidence that will enable important questions around child oral health
column8: social and emotional wellbeing
column9: school performance and economic productivity to be answered."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2017219^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2017219"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Improving the health system’s response when patients are harmed: a mixed-methods study
column2: Partnership Projects"^"When patients are harmed
column3: it is imperative that health care organisations respond to and learn from them and prevent other patients suffering a similar incident. However
column4: there is no evidence that systems for managing incidents reduce more incidents causing harm to patients. We will work closely with four jurisdiction's health systems to research current practices
column5: test interventions that are occurring in health services
column6: and undertake a world-first simulation trial using artificial intelligence."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2017496^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2017496"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Sleep for Strong Souls (3S): Multisectoral partnership and co-designed solutions to improve the sleep health of First Nations Adolescents
column2: Partnership Projects"^"1 in 3 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander adolescents struggle with poor sleep
column3: yet their sleep health needs remains unmet. In collaboration with community members
column4: the project team and partner organisations are working together to co-design a sleep health program and resources
column5: build local capacity
column6: and embed culturally responsive and context responsive sleep health care in preventive programs and health system to meet the sleep health needs of First Nations adolescents."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018981^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018981"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"NAVICARE: Implementing
column2: scaling up and sustaining a co-designed care navigation model to improve mental health service access in regional Australia
column3: Partnership Projects"^"One in five Australians experience mental ill health each year. In regional Australia
column4: mental health services are harder to access than in urban areas. We developed a new model of care with regional communities to address this. A local person assists people in navigating how to access the best mental health care
column5: which has been shown to be beneficial. This project will evaluate the new model of care in multiple regional sites in Queensland and potential scaling up across Australia."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019034^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019034"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Determining the impact of the Melbourne Supervised Injecting Rooms on health and social outcomess
column2: Partnership Projects"^"The Melbourne Supervised Injecting Room opened in North Richmond in 2018 and has since become one of the busiest in the world. A second MSIR will open in Melbourne's Central Business District. By establishing SIRX
column3: a prospective cohort of MSIR service users
column4: this study will provide new highest-quality evidence about the effectiveness of the MSIRS to inform ongoing policy and practice around supervised injecting facilities over the coming decade."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019085^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019085"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Can an aftercare service reduce suicide risk in young people? An effectiveness-implementation evaluation
column2: Partnership Projects"^"This project responds to rising rates of youth suicide. It will evaluate a youth aftercare service designed to support young people who have presented to the emergency department with suicide risk. The project will employ different methodologies to understand the acceptability and effectiveness of the service from the perspectives of young people
column3: families and professionals. It represents a partnership between the University of Melbourne
column4: Orygen and the Victorian Department of Health."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019735^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019735"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Integrating mathematical modelling and public health surveillance to improve control of epidemic and pandemic respiratory infections in Australia
column2: Partnership Projects"^"Australia has had a highly successful response to COVID-19 by global standards but this success relied on real-time development of public health responses including new surveillance of trends and interventions and analysis through newly developed models. We seek to embed efficient and relevant surveillance and real-time analysis within jurisdictional responses to COVID-19 and other important respiratory infections
column3: through partnerships with NSW
column4: ACT and QLD health departments."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018793^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018793"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Engineered tumour-homing bacteria that safely turn up the heat on immunologically cold colorectal cancers
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The most prevalent colorectal cancer subtype has a low mutational burden and does not respond well to immunotherapies. The immune agonist anti-CD40 can drive immune infiltration into this cancer subtype and can reduce tumour burden in a mouse model that faithfully recapitulates the disease
column3: however induces severe toxicity. This project will determine if expressing CD40 agonists in probiotic bacteria can be used to reduce this toxicity and effectively suppress colorectal cancer growth."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018797^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018797"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting the hepatitis B e antigen as a novel therapeutic approach
column2: Ideas Grants"^"There is no cure for chronic hepatitis B virus disease. The secreted hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg) is a major cause of chronic infection
column3: and its removal by host immune responses improves patient health. Current antiviral therapy does not specifically target this protein. We have developed novel methods to reducing HBeAg levels in a mouse model of HBV persistence. This proposal will progress these findings towards a novel therapeutic approach to treat HBeAg-+ve chronic hepatitis B."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018825^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018825"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Characterization of the Germline Regulatory Landscape
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Human fertility requires the generation of gametes (oocytes and sperm) that combine to produce an embryo. The aim of this research program is to identify genes and proteins that control gamete production. The biochemical pathways under study could be targeted by drugs. Therefore
column3: new knowledge generated in this project has the potential to identify processes and pathways that are directly relevant to reproduction-related disease
column4: infertility and in vitro fertilization."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018833^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018833"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Accelerating messenger RNA (mRNA) therapeutics by cracking the epitranscriptomic code
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The remarkable efficacy of SARS-CoV-2 vaccines based on messenger RNA (mRNA) has highlighted the extraordinary potential of mRNA technologies and has secured the promise of mRNA as a therapeutic modality for multiple diseases. This research project builds on a recent breakthrough from my research that enables an unprecedented characterisation of the chemical composition of individual mRNA molecules to uphold this promise and accelerate mRNA exploration and design for therapeutic development."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018835^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018835"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Molecular pathways that control platelet production
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Platelets are small cells that circulate by the millions in the bloodstream and are primarily responsible for sealing a blood vessel when the vessel is damaged. The mechanisms controlling platelet production are not well understood. We have discovered that by inhibiting ribosomal biogenesis
column3: we can rapidly increase platelet production. This will be of enormous benefit in clinical settings where platelets are low and catastrophic bleeding is likely."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018880^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018880"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Dissecting the intracellular lifestyle of lethal Staphylococcus aureus
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Staphylococcus aureus (golden staph) cause infection of the bloodstream
column3: a serious condition with a high death toll in patients. Despite years of research
column4: it is still unclear how these bacteria hide into human cells to escape our immune system and current antibiotics. Here
column5: we propose a research programme to understand the molecular strategies used by golden staph to cause these serious infections. Our findings will help design new drugs to treat severe bacterial infections."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018888^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018888"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting molecular ageing pathways for the treatment of chronic pain
column2: Ideas Grants"^"One in five Australians lives with chronic pain and this prevalence rises to one in three people over the age of 65. Available treatments for pain are often ineffective and associated with dose-limiting side effects. This project aims to explore a potential new avenue of pain research
column3: and the knowledge gained is expected to provide a breakthrough understanding of the interplay between chronic pain and cellular ageing
column4: and nonetheless will lay the groundwork for numerous applications."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018895^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018895"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Unmask HIV latency through disruption of HIV synapses
column2: Ideas Grants"^"HIV synapses enable cell-cell transmission to overcome anti-retroviral therapeutics and broadly neutralising anti-HIV antibodies. Our ground-breaking report on the Ca2+-HIV synapse biology will: (i) improve efficiency of HIV therapeutics; and (ii) show how HIV latently infected cells can be sensitised for destruction. A cross-disciplinary approach involving molecular virology
column3: cell biology
column4: and machine learning will be used to accelerate our discovery for its application at the clinic."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018897^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018897"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Preventing a nephron deficit in premature offspring
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Many premature babies are born with a low number of functional units (nephrons) in their kidneys and an increased risk of developing chronic kidney disease. Strategies to prevent a nephron deficit in preterm offspring are required. We have found that manipulating maternal nutrition during lactation can rescue a nephron deficit. We will determine the multidimensional impact of dietary macronutrients on maternal milk composition and nephron endowment following premature birth."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018916^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018916"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Assessing benefits of extended genomic newborn screening at population scale in infants from Generation Victoria
column2: Ideas Grants"^"There are over 7
column3: 000 rare diseases with the average age of diagnosis being 4 years. Newborn screening using genomics could identify these children at a younger age and deliver new therapies at birth to offer the most chance of health benefits. We will test effectiveness of a novel genomic workflow called EpiGNs to detect harmful changes to genes on the whole-of-state birth cohort (GenV) of 100
column4: 000 infants. This will enable its implementation as a new model for genomic newborn screening."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018919^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018919"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Regulators of Tau Pathology Induced by Exosomal and Vesicle-free Tau Seeds
column2: Ideas Grants"^"In Alzheimer’s disease
column3: misfolded forms of the protein tau known as seeds propagate from neuron to neuron allowing for spreading and progression of tau pathology. We discovered novel genes that regulate this process. We will dissect how these regulators enable the disease
column4: and whether their manipulation can modulate or stop tau pathology in cells and in brains. We expect that by understanding how different tau seeds cause tau pathology
column5: our research will also reveal novel therapeutic targets."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018947^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018947"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Personalising diagnosis and treatment of Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection
column2: Ideas Grants"^"We will develop a novel blood test that measures the antibody glycocode and informs on the individual immune status of patients. This new test will improve and significantly accelerate personalised diagnosis and treatment of patients suffering from infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa
column3: a pathogen classified by the World Health Organisation at the highest threat level due to it becoming increasingly resistant to last resort antibiotics."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018951^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018951"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"New Approaches for Sensitising Metastatic Colorectal Cancer to Immunotherapy
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Immunotherapy is an approach that takes advantage of the body’s own immune system to attack cancer cells. This therapy that has produced long term benefit for patients with many different types of advanced cancers
column3: but has had limited benefit for patients with bowel cancer. In this application we are using cutting edge techniques to identify new ways to use immunotherapy to improve outcomes for patients with advanced bowel cancer."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018980^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018980"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Defining the roles of O-linked glycosylation on Burkholderia virulence
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Burkholderia infections are associated with high mortality rates especially within immunocompromised individuals. Due to this there is an urgent need to identify bacterial factors which can be targeted to reduce the disease burden of these infections. Within this grant we aim to identify how a specific set of proteins
column3: glycoproteins
column4: contribute to Burkholderia virulence with the goal to identify next generation vaccines and anti-microbial targets."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018988^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018988"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A novel brain circuit inhibiting airway interoceptive processing
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The air passages and lungs are exposed to the external environment through the air that is breathed. It is therefore important that they can sense danger signals present in air
column3: such as toxins or irritants
column4: that might compromise breathing. This sensory system is poorly described. We will investigate brain circuits regulating airway irritant detection when air quality is compromised by smoke arising from bush fires. The findings will inform the severe health impacts of environmental pollutants."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018997^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018997"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Novel biomarkers and drug targets for pharmacoresistant epilepsy
column2: Ideas Grants"^"In one-third of epilepsy patients
column3: currently available antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) do not control seizures. Recurrent seizures threaten life and impair its quality; hence
column4: there is a clear need to discover new AEDs. In addition
column5: there is currently no way to accurately predict which and how individuals will respond to a specific or any AED. The proposed research aims identify new AED targets and predict the right (and wrong) drugs for an epilepsy patient from the outset."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019011^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019011"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Thalamic plasticity following cortical damage: recovery of vision
column2: Ideas Grants"^"This project will investigate how neuroplasticity can contribute to vision recovery in adult brain
column3: following damage to one of its key nodes. Normally
column4: such lesions render the person blind
column5: but some slight improvement occurs over time. We will test the extent to which newborn neurons can be integrated to other parts of this circuit in a manner that explains the partial recovery of vision
column6: and whether a rehabilitation therapy can boost this process."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019014^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019014"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Engineering bone marrow-derived stromal cells to express anti-fibrotic cargo as a treatment for chronic kidney disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Although a number of organs can repair themselves from mild injury
column3: when subjected to persistent injury
column4: they fail to do so. As a result
column5: they undergo organ scarring (fibrosis) and a progressive loss of function. As current therapies fail to effectively stop this scarring process
column6: we aim to engineer human bone marrow-derived stromal cells to express an anti-fibrotic agent (serelaxin)
column7: to deliver the therapeutic potential of this combination therapy as a treatment of chronic kidney disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019024^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019024"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Harnessing and understanding Tr1 cells in inflammation
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Inflammation that is inappropriately directed causes a range of important human diseases and current therapies for these diseases are limited. New methods or identification of new mechanisms that can be exploited to control persistent inflammation are therefore urgently required. In this project we will explore the biology of Type-I regulatory T cells (Tr1 cells)
column3: which appear to play an important role in the control of inflammation."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019032^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019032"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Codon bias and the role of tRNA modifications in cancer
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Cancer is characterised by high rate of cell growth and proliferation. Cancer cells need to increase their biomass to divide and this is dependent on the the synthesis of proteins. We have recently discovered that transfer RNAs
column3: the small molecules carrying the building blocs required for protein synthesis
column4: are chemicaly modified and that these modifications could be targeted to strongly inhibit tumour growth and progression in a wide array of cancers."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019058^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019058"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"How does metabolic conditioning of the host environment enhance persistence of Haemophilus influenzae infections?
column2: Ideas Grants"^"To thrive
column3: bacterial pathogens infecting humans require access to high quality nutrients
column4: but our understanding of pathogen nutrition is limited. We will examine how virulence of the respiratory pathogen Haemophilus influenzae (NTHi) is determined by nutrient availability in the human respiratory tract and how the presence of NTHi changes the way human cells detect infection. The project will identify targets for the development of novel types of antimicrobials that starve NTHi of key nutrients."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019079^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019079"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Shedding new light on vagal nerve stimulation
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Inflammation is a complex response to injury and overactivation of inflammation can lead to damage to the host. Stimulating the vagus nerve (VNS) is known to have powerful anti-inflammatory effects but the mechanisms are not well understood. We will use cutting-edge molecular tools in a pre-clinical model of inflammation to allow us to selectively target branches of the vagus nerve going to specific organs and will determine the contribution of each organ to the anti-inflammatory effect of VNS."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019087^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019087"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Interrupting suicides in public places: Using CCTV to understand
column2: detect
column3: and respond to behaviours prior to a suicide attempt
column4: Ideas Grants"^"Suicide is a leading cause of death
column5: and 30% of all suicides occur in public places. Despite this frequency
column6: we lack an understanding of the key behaviours people exhibit prior to a suicide attempt in different public settings
column7: and we lack the tools to identify these behaviours at the scale needed for those responsible for those public sites to meaningfully respond. This project will characterise
column8: detect
column9: and respond to behaviours which precede suicide attempts in public places in Australia."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019093^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019093"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Improving estimates of antimalarial drug resistance
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Antimalarial drugs are essential for the elimination of malaria. Resistance to all currently available antimalarials
column3: including the pivotal artemisinin derivatives
column4: has emerged and is spreading. This project aims to generate the first data-driven
column5: predictive maps of the changing landscape of artemisinin resistance in Asia. These maps fill in the gaps where no information is available and can be used by health agencies to guide new polices about where and when the drug is appropriate to use."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019097^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019097"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A metabolic enzyme as a target for controlling tumourigenesis
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Cancer is the leading cause of death in Australia and globally. The majority of cancers are associated with metabolic alterations in tumours. We have identified a key role for an enzyme involved in fatty acid metabolism which impairs immune responses involved in tumour-control and drives cancer. This research aims to investigate key mechanisms of how this enzyme promotes tumour progression and establish the development of inhibitors of this enzyme that can be applied to different cancers."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019100^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019100"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Finding Biomarkers and Treatments for Vascular Dementia
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Vascular dementia (VaD) occurs as a result of brain hypoperfusion and represents the second most common type of dementia after Alzheimer's disease. Currently
column3: no specific treatments for VaD exist due to incomplete understanding of the underlying pathophysiology. We are studying inflammasomes as a new therapeutic target to treat VaD. In the next 5 years
column4: this project expects to discover translatable preclinical targets and therapies to treat VaD
column5: and novel biomarkers to diagnosis VaD in humans."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019101^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019101"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Combining genetics and genomics to tackle ovarian cancer.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Recent studies have identified DNA markers within the human genome that are associated with an increased risk of ovarian cancer. Most of these markers are located in noncoding regions
column3: therefore the key genes driving risk are not known. This proposal will identify the target genes at all ovarian cancer risk regions and assess gene function in cancer development. Understanding how DNA variation contributes to ovarian cancer will provide new avenues for future prevention or treatment."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019139^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019139"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Repurposing the in-clinic PCSK9 inhibitor evolocumab to enhance Gemcitabine/Abraxane chemotherapy in pancreatic cancer guided by single-cell intravital imaging
column2: Ideas Grants"^"During pancreatic cancer development
column3: cancer cells undergo metabolic rewiring in order to survive
column4: grow and spread. This Ideas Grant will use advanced animal imaging and unique patient-derived pancreatic cancer specimens to explore targeting PCSK9 with drugs already in the clinic
column5: in combination with chemotherapy. This new dual therapy could significantly improve treatment response in this devastating disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019152^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019152"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Multi-species malaria transmission modelling to inform policy decisions
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Most malaria cases are caused by two parasite species. While many countries with malaria have both species
column3: decisions about treatment and control of malaria rely on data and mathematical models on one species. Working with policy makers
column4: we have built a novel model that includes both species. This model will explore how species interact and determine how to allocate money on strategies that will maximise health benefits
column5: ensuring that we reach malaria elimination as quickly as possible."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019153^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019153"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The newly-discovered splenic Plasmodium reservoir as a target to reduce global malaria burden
column2: Ideas Grants"^"We have recently discovered that the spleen is the major reservoir for malaria parasites in natural human malaria infections. There are significant concerns that this previously-unrecognised reservoir underlies the major challenges we face to eliminate this disease. We will use the world’s only collection of spleen and blood samples from untreated human infections
column3: to study the splenic malaria reservoir
column4: uncover its biology and identify new ways to improve malaria elimination strategies."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019160^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019160"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Pharmaceutical Development of Innovative "Trojan Horse" Anti-Cancer Agents that Inhibit Desmoplasia by Reprogramming Signalling
column2: Ideas Grants"^"We discovered the new PPPT agents that reprogram Sonic Hedgehog Signalling to Inhibit Desmoplasia. Another breakthrough is that these agents totally prevent myoglobin (Mb) oxidation
column3: which was an issue with our clinically trialled agent
column4: DpC Underlining Innovation
column5: no other drug currently available prevents deleterious Mb oxidation
column6: targets the deadly "Triad of Death" (metastasis
column7: Pgp resistance
column8: primary tumour growth)
column9: and & inhibits bidirectional oncogenic signalling that leads to desmoplasia"^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019167^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019167"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Oxidised Cholesterols as Key Regulators of Host Immunity to Tuberculosis
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Despite available antibiotics we have failed to eradicate TB. It is therefore critically important to elucidate the host immune factors that are required for effective containment of the bacteria that cause TB. We have identified that oxidised cholesterols play a critical role in attracting immune cells and containing the infection. This project will deliver further insights into this pathway which can ultimately be targeted with drugs to prevent the development of TB."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019196^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019196"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The Mental Health Impact of Childhood SARS-CoV-2
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Children have key differences in ACE2
column3: the receptor by which SARS-CoV-2 enters host cells
column4: that may make them especially vulnerable to lasting brain damage. We show that a single ACE2 inhibition in juvenile rats leads to lasting anxiety- and depressive-like behaviour and associated brain changes. We hypothesize these effects will be worse the younger COVID-19 occurs. We will reveal the potential for COVID-19 to critically impact children
column5: changing the approach to child health in this pandemic."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019231^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019231"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Firing up oncolytic vectors: viral based strategies to repurpose necroptosis
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Necroptosis is an inflammatory form of cell death that could be harnessed to turn on the immune response and fight tumours. This research will study necroptosis signalling and adapt existing approved oncolytic viruses to deliver proteins that initiate necroptosis specifically within the tumour. Melanoma and colorectal cancer models will be used for proof-of-principle. These second-generation therapeutics could work in concert with existing immunotherapies to provide superior cancer control."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019254^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019254"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Size matters: ECM regulation in pregnancy success
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Complications affect ~15% of pregnancies. Appropriate regulation of cellular environment is required for correct implantation and placental formation
column3: but disease will occur if it is defective. To diagnose and treat pregnancy complications we must first understand how implantation and the placenta form. This project will investigate mouse models with abnormal implantation and placental development. It will determine how and why disease occurs and investigate potential therapeutic interventions."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019264^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019264"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Novel Targeted Therapies for Chronic Pain
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Using single cell sequencing technology
column3: we have identified several drivers underlying spinal hyperexcitability in neuropathic pain. Here we will confirm our findings with new spatial technology that reconstructs the spinal anatomical map and assess the effectiveness of 1) boosting inhibition via cell transplants and 2) suppressing hyperexcitability via CRISPR. Our work leverages new functional genomic technologies to rapidly deliver new safe
column4: effective pain management approaches to the clinic."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019271^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019271"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Neural circuits that control movement: from mice to humans
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Parkinson’s disease (PD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder affecting nearly 1% of individuals older than 60
column3: one of the fastest growing neurological disorders
column4: generating a substantial burden patients
column5: and caregivers
column6: with the total cost to the community in excess of $10 billion / year. Many patients with PD develop Freezing of gait. This grant aim to understand what causes freezing of gait in PD and new ways treat the effects of PD on gait and movement."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019296^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019296"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"An Achilles’ heel of ovarian cancer: targeting ARID1A mutant tumours
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Five-year survival for most women with ovarian cancer is poor
column3: with drug resistance a major problem
column4: especially once relapsed. Outcomes are particularly dismal for the sub-type ovarian clear cell carcinoma that is particularly drug resistant. We are looking beyond the DNA to the “epigenome” to target factors involved in changing the landscape of DNA in order to identify new therapies to treat ovarian cancer
column5: overcome chemoresistance and extend the lives of women with this malignancy."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019329^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019329"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Exploiting the gene transfer synergies of AAV and LNP to achieve highly efficient genome editing in the human liver
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Genome editing is set to revolutionise the face of modern medicine. This project will develop a cutting-edge genome editing treatment carefully designed for therapeutic readiness. The team will exploit privileged access to explanted patient and donor livers as well as elite gene delivery systems to advance an innovative approach that will provide the foundations for a future clinical trial in children with severe and potentially fatal urea cycle disorders without further preclinical studies."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019352^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019352"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A therapeutic solution for respiratory RNA viruses that corrects the patient’s TLR7-dependent inflammatory response
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Respiratory virus infections such as COVID-19 and influenza cause mild to severe complications in humans
column3: often resulting in patient death. With limitations in current treatments
column4: there is an urgent need for novel therapeutics to combat these and other viruses. We propose a drug strategy that attacks a critical point in the viral pathogenesis process. With the knowledge of this control point
column5: we developed a drug and will evaluate its efficacy for treating COVID-19
column6: influenza and the common cold."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019360^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019360"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Gene regulatory mechanisms by autoimmune risk loci in primary human cells
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The genetic causes of autoimmune disease (where the immune system attacks our own body) are poorly understood. While many small changes in patient DNA are linked with autoimmunity
column3: for more than 90% of these mutations we do not know which genes or cells are affected. We will discover the genes controlled by autoimmune-specific DNA changes and how they disrupt immune cell function. This will discover how autoimmune diseases develop and provide information needed to develop new treatments."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019361^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019361"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The Role of Salt in Obesity Development
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Modern diets high in sugar and fat have contributed significantly to the prevalence of obesity. However
column3: tackling obesity by lowering dietary fat content in our diets has not succeeded to the degree that we expected. As a result
column4: obesity is on the rise. Recently
column5: my team has discovered that high salt intake
column6: often present in a high fat diet
column7: could be a key and overlooked factor that potentially contributes to the development and progression of obesity
column8: especially combined with high fat feeding."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019372^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019372"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Developing an in vitro human sleep system
column2: Ideas Grants"^"This project aims to understand the formation of cells in the brain that are critical for controlling sleep. These sleep neurons are often affected in sleep disorders such as narcolepsy
column3: a condition involving sudden attacks of sleep that affects 1/2
column4: 000 humans. By understanding how sleep neurons develop within the brain we will be able to generate sleep neurons from stem cells. This will pave the way for future bench-to-clinic transplantation experiments to alleviate narcolepsy."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019383^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019383"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Stimulating Biomimetic Neuroplasticity to Develop New Cell Therapy for Blindness.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The loss of light-sensing photoreceptors is a leading cause of blindness. Severe cases have no treatments
column3: and we thus aim to develop effective cell therapy by transplantation of photoreceptors to restore vision. We can generate millions of these cells from stem cell generated mini-retinas (organoids)
column4: but transplantation outcomes are still ineffective. Here we will test whether electrical stimulation improves photoreceptor transplantation in animal models to rescue sight and treat blindness."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019404^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019404"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Microelectrode recordings from the vagus nerve in awake humans
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The vagus nerve is an important nerve that controls the heart
column3: lungs and gut. It exits the brain and travels with the carotid arteries and jugular veins in the neck. As such it has defied direct investigation in humans
column4: but here we have developed a means of inserting metal microelectrodes into this nerve and recording signals going to and from the brain. This approach promises to provide much needed information on how the organ control provided by the vagus nerve is affected in disease states."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019416^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019416"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The Neurokinin 3 Receptor is a New Target for the Treatment of Autism Spectrum Disorder.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"No treatment has been shown to be effective in treating the core symptoms of autism spectrum disorder. We have discovered a molecule
column3: named NK3R
column4: which plays a key role in the development of autism. Studying how this molecule works in mouse models of autism will help us to better understand the disorder and enable us to identify the signs of abnormal brain function. The outcomes of this 4-year research will ultimately enable us to propose new strategies to treat the symptoms of autism."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019420^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019420"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Human anogenital mononuclear phagocytes in tranmission of HIV
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Dendritic cells (DC) are the first cells to interact with HIV and the program has discovered three that transmit the virus. This proposal will define the receptors these DCs use to bind HIV and how they activate the immune system which is important information for vaccine design. Using new technologies that the research program has pioneered
column3: the proposal will also define how HIV transmission occurs in human inflamed tissue for the first time which will lead to better prophylactic treatments."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019437^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019437"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting phenotypic plasticity to treat chemotherapy-resistant cancer
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Some cancer cells are very aggressive. Those cells are the reason why cancers become resistant to chemotherapy. If we can eradicate the aggressive cells we can improve survival outcomes for patients. We have identified a new target
column3: SULF1
column4: that is required for cancer cells to be aggressive and evade chemotherapy. We now aim to show that by targeting SULF1 we can stop cancers from spreading and make them susceptible to chemotherapy."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019442^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019442"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Improving parent and child emotion regulation in early childhood to reduce population rates of child mental illness
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The project develops and trials a new smartphone intervention that will radically redesign models for parenting support and the prevention of child mental illness. We aim to engage both mothers and fathers of children 2-4 years
column3: and will optimise parent and child outcomes: (a) tailoring parenting resources to be relevant to specific parenting situations; (b) including Indigenous-led
column4: culturally-derived content; and (c) using machine learning to personalise the delivery of 3 types of support."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019447^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019447"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Understanding clonal hierarchy and tissue reconstitution post injury
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Millions of blood cells are made by the body every day in specialised organ compartments. T-cells are white blood cells and make up an important part of the immune system that fights infections and cancer. In this study
column3: we aim to find out how blood stem cells turn into T-cells as they move through different organ compartments. We are trying to understand how the blood system is regenerated after damage from cancer therapies by stem cell transplants to improve patient outcomes."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019455^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019455"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Harnessing the therapeutic potential of mesenchymal stromal cells by priming via surface microtopographies
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs) promote tissue repair
column3: but lose their beneficial properties during the production process outside the body. We have found that culturing MSCs on surfaces with microscale patterns alters their properties. We will investigate how these surfaces improve the therapeutic activity of MSCs and develop a technology to allow this to be done at a large scale. Our discoveries will enable higher quality MSCs to be produced for therapies for a wide range of diseases."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019477^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019477"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Developing PKCepsilon-Degrading PROTACs as Dual-Action Agents to Treat Type 2 Diabetes
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is reaching epidemic proportions worldwide
column3: and involves poor insulin production and decreased insulin sensitivity. This collaboration between diabetes researchers and medicinal chemists will translate basic science
column4: demonstrating that inhibiting one enzyme can improve both these defects
column5: into the generation of lead compounds that block this target. We will test inhibitors in models of T2D
column6: providing proof-of-principle for their further development."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019488^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019488"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A calcium influx pathway regulates adaptive cancer drug tolerance
column2: Ideas Grants"^"New drugs for the treatment of melanoma
column3: lung and other cancers has revolutionised therapeutic approaches for many patients. However
column4: in many cases
column5: cancers become tolerant and eventually completely resistant to these new therapies. This project team has identified a specific new drug target that may hold the key to preventing or reversing the tolerance to these therapies. This grant will focus on defining the therapeutic opportunities that this new drug target offers."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019492^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019492"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Hijacking enzymes that charge tRNAs: a new strategy for development of anti-malarials.
