column2: Ideas Grants"^"New drugs are desperately needed to treat drug-resistant pathogens. We have discovered a class of inhibitor molecules
column3: called “nukes”
column4: that target enzymes powered by the energy molecule
column5: ATP. “Nukes” induce the enzymes to generate their own inhibitors
column6: via a mechanism that we call “reaction hijacking”. This project will investigate the design principles for making bespoke “nukes”
column7: which will have applications in curing malaria
column8: as well as infections with antimicrobial resistant bacteria."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019552^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019552"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Unlocking the potential of cancer associated fibroblasts to defeat pancreatic cancer.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"There are key knowledge gaps in understanding the complex metabolism of the pancreatic cancer tumour microenvironment and how this influences poor response to current therapies. My research will directly address this by characterizing how the pancreatic cancer tumour microenvironment evolves as cancer progresses and its response to current therapies. This will inform development of more effective treatment strategies that can overcome resistance and improve patient outcomes."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019558^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019558"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Dysregulated lymphatic vasculature in the pathogenesis of bronchopulmonary dysplasia
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Bronchopulmonary dysplasia is a severe lung disease that is a main cause of disability and death in premature infants and there is no cure. We have found that a factor that enhances the growth of lung lymphatic vessels
column3: essential fluid channels
column4: protects the lung from structural and functional damage. We will used advanced research methods to define the role of these vessels in this disease to turn our discovery into new treatments that can help these tiny lungs develop and function normally."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019572^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019572"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting pyroptosis to limit the severity of influenza virus infections
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Highly pathogenic influenza A virus infections are associated with highly mortality rates. To facilitate the development of improved treatments for severe IAV infections
column3: this project will advance our fundamental knowledge of the mechanisms by which the host and virus interact and elucidate how the host's immune system can be therapeutically modulated to limit disease severity. These studies are crucial to ensure we are better prepared for the next pandemic."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019595^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019595"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The role of genetic compensation in modifying disease severity and potential therapeutic application
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Harmful mutations in the genome have significant impacts on health and survival. Recent studies have identified individuals with mutations
column3: that are expected to cause disease
column4: yet they are remarkably asymptomatic. Growing evidence suggests this is due to compensatory activation of other genes
column5: masking the effects of damaging mutations. This project examines the trigger for this compensation to determine its relevance in preventing disease and potential use in genetic therapies."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019655^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019655"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Tracking transcriptional evolution in breast cancer using circulating tumour DNA
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Tumours shed small amounts of DNA into the patient’s bloodstream. Therefore
column3: a simple blood test gives us a window to study the cancer
column4: offering a non-invasive alternative to tissue biopsies. This project will use circulating tumour DNA in blood to study how cancer evolves and becomes resistant to treatment in advanced breast cancer where only 25% of patients survive beyond five years. Our method is generalisable across tumour types and has the potential to transform real-time cancer monitoring."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019670^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019670"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Novel methods to improve reporting and peer review of systematic reviews of health evidence
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Systematic reviews focus on the totality of available evidence on a given question
column3: and often underpin healthcare decision making. However
column4: the reporting of many systematic reviews is suboptimal. This amounts to wasted research effort
column5: and systematic reviews that cannot reliably inform clinical and public health guidelines. This proposal will develop guidance and web apps to help researchers produce systematic reviews that better meet the needs of stakeholders
column6: hence improving health outcomes."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019689^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019689"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"On target and on time
column2: advancing molecular diagnosis of complicated childhood pneumonia for better patient outcomes and vaccine strategies
column3: Ideas Grants"^"During pleural infection fluid pools in the lung. Identifying the bacterial cause is important
column4: so children can receive the right antibiotics. Our new laboratory test can better identify bacteria than traditional methods. We will use our test to determine which bacteria are causing pleural infection in Asian children and how our test will improve clinical care. We will apply other molecular methods to determine how many cases could be prevented by pneumococcal vaccines."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019722^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019722"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting Impaired Glucose Sensing in the Brain to Improve Glucose Homeostasis in T2D
column2: Ideas Grants"^"New drugs working in novel ways are needed to treat type 2 diabetes
column3: because current treatments fail to prevent the progression of the disease. We showed that an enzyme
column4: PKCe
column5: interferes with the the sensitivity of the brain to glucose
column6: so that it fails to respond to rising glucose levels. We will investigate how this enzyme prevents the brain from controlling blood glucose levels
column7: and will also test whether blocking PKCe is able to improve glucose sensing
column8: paving the way for drug development."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019729^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019729"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Determination of “actionable vaccine targets” for breast cancer immunotherapy
column2: Ideas Grants"^"In recent years
column3: immunotherapy brings hopes for treatment of incurable cancer. However
column4: understanding the right target for immunotherapy is critical and challenging. We have developed new technologies and will explore new classes of antigens that can form targets of vaccines and immunotherapy in breast cancer."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019765^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019765"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Harnessing metabolism to improve the outcomes of deadly fungal infections
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Life-threatening infections are complications of surgery
column3: chemotherapy and organ transplantations. Therapies are limited and mortality is high. This project studies how metabolic adaptations could be harnessed to provide energy for effective immune responses and maintaining the function of vital organs during life-threatening fungal infection. We expect that the knowledge gained in this project will inform therapeutic innovations aimed at improving patient survival of serious fungal infections."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019767^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019767"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Characterising a novel toxin regulatory mechanism from the new hypervirulent Streptococcal pyogenes M1uk lineage in Australia
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Group A Streptococcus (GAS) is a strictly human pathogen that ranks among the top 10 infectious disease killers. A new variant of GAS expressing a novel set of bacterial toxins has emerged in the United Kingdom
column3: known as M1UK. The M1UK lineage is associated with increases in invasive disease. We have now detected that this new GAS M1UK lineage has arrived in Australia. This proposal will define the disease mechanisms underlying this new health threat to Australian and global health."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019780^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019780"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"GABA-A receptor variants in developmental and epileptic encephalopathy: a bench to bedside approach.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Developmental epileptic encephalopathies (DEE) are a group of severe brain disorders characterised by childhood seizures that are often treatment resistant. We identified that hyperactivity in GABA-A receptors (the major inhibitory protein of the brain) caused by novel mutations are responsible for treatment resistant DEE. With a team of scientists
column3: geneticists
column4: and neurologists we aim to decipher the role of these receptors in brain networks and translate our discoveries to the clinic."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019804^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019804"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Testing a preventative strategy for sudden unexpected death in epilepsy (SUDEP) in mouse models based on human genetics
column2: Ideas Grants"^"What causes sudden unexpected death in epilepsy (SUDEP) in unclear
column3: although irregular heart rhythm is suspected to play a role. We recently found that genetic changes in the heart could help identify epilepsy patients who are at higher risk of SUDEP. By introducing these genetic changes in research models
column4: we can understand how the heart responds in events leading up to SUDEP
column5: and if improving heart function with currently available therapies can reduce SUDEP risk."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019818^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019818"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Inspire the bright side of kidney fibroblasts to prevent and cure chronic kidney disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is a worldwide public health problem. Current clinical strategies for CKD are largely ineffective. Kidney transplantation and dialysis are the only options for the management of end stage kidney disease (ESKD)
column3: which results in a significant personal and societal burden. This project will innovatively promote the good function but hinder the bad role of kidney fibroblasts thereby conferring renal protection in CKD through targeting En-1 gene function."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019831^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019831"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Healing Spirit
column2: Healing Minds: Co-designed healing program to promote social and emotional wellbeing of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander youth.
column3: Ideas Grants"^"The Healing Spirits
column4: Healing Minds project will co-design and evaluate a healing program under the leadership of First Nations youth that are most at risk of suffering from undetected and under-supported suicidal ideations and behaviours. The resulting program is anticipated to incorporate peer mentorship with activities focused on 1) promoting empowerment and wellbeing
column5: 2) building social connections
column6: 3) facilitating emotional regulation
column7: and 4) encouraging help seeking behaviours."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019843^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019843"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting metastatic pancreatic cancer via selective inhibition of oncogenic JNK
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Pancreatic cancer is one of the most lethal forms of human cancer. The current standard-of-care chemotherapies are known to be largely ineffective against advanced disease and new treatment options are urgently needed. We have developed a novel drug (K12) that selectively inhibits the metastatic function of JNK in breast cancer
column3: and shown that this oncogenic pathway is conserved in pancreatic cancer. We will now test the utility of our novel drug as a treatment for metastatic pancreatic cancer."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019853^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019853"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Developing novel therapeutic strategies and predictive biomarkers in Pancreatic Cancer
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Pancreatic cancers are frequent and have extremely poor outcomes. Very few treatments are available for patients with this disease. Candidate drugs have recently emerged to block specific genetic modifications found in this cancer
column3: but tumour cells can often evade these treatments. Here
column4: we will combine innovative genetic and cellular analyses to design specific drug combinations preventing the ability of pancreatic cancers to escape treatment and thus improving the treatment of this disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019859^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019859"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Identifying modifiable health and social determinants of 'deaths of despair': learning from the past to shape new interventions
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Deaths of despair (due to alcohol
column3: other substances
column4: and suicide) have risen dramatically in Australia and globally over the last 20 years. These are avoidable deaths given timely and targeted intervention. Using population-based data linkage
column5: novel machine learning methods
column6: and mathematical modelling
column7: we will examine risk factors
column8: and model the impact of potential interventions to reduce deaths of despair to inform targeted strategies and policies to prevent these premature deaths occurring."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019867^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019867"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A new brain circuit of GPR75 to regulate metabolism
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The increasing prevalence of obesity represents a major public health crisis worldwide. In Australia
column3: almost two-thirds of adults are overweight or obese. GPR75 is a gene recently identified to play an important role in body weight regulation. Indeed
column4: humans and mice carrying loss-of-function mutations of GPR75 are protected from obesity. This proposal will determine the specific site of action
column5: and underlying mechanism of GPR75-induced protection against obesity
column6: and its related hypertension."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019871^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019871"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Novel regulation of a fundamental host defence pathway by human herpesviruses
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) and herpes simplex virus (HSV) often cause serious disease. Eg
column3: HCMV is the leading infectious cause of birth defects and a major complication in transplant patients
column4: and HSV causes cold sores that can be life-threatening in those with a compromised immune system. We have identified a novel way that these viruses can control the host response to infection. This research proposal will investigate this control to identify potential ways to control viral disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019889^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019889"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A novel therapeutic target for obesity: Salt-inducible kinase 3 (SIK3)
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The overconsumption of high calorie foods together with sedentary lifestyle are key reasons for the obesity epidemic. The brain plays an important role in controlling the amount of energy intake and expenditure. However
column3: how the brain controls these physiological processes remain poorly understood. In this proposal
column4: we aim to study a new molecule in the brain to control appetite and body weight and establish this molecule as a potential new therapeutic target for the treatment of obesity."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019904^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019904"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Endothelial origin of left ventricular non compaction
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Primary cardiac myopathies refers to inheritable heart diseases
column3: characterised by weak heart muscles. A common form of these disorders is left ventricular non-compaction (LVNC). By enlarge our understanding of the cellular origin of these cardiac defects is still unknown. This proposal will investigate how defects in blood vessel formation during embryogenesis is a cause of LVNC. This work will help to risk-stratify patients with LVNC cardiac disease to better manage adverse outcome."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019912^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019912"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Understanding how platelets prevent fetal and neonatal stroke
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Stroke is caused by either abnormal clotting or by unchecked bleeding; both result in devastating damage to the brain
column3: causing death or life-long disability. Newborn children with low platelet numbers are at high risk of bleeding-associated stroke
column4: yet we do not understand why. We hypothesize that the cause is rooted in early development. We will identify when these problems arise and define therapeutic strategies for the prevention or amelioration of neonatal stroke."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019920^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019920"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Uncovering and detecting placental dysfunction in late-onset preeclampsia
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Preeclampsia is a life-threatening disease of pregnancy with grave immediate and life-long consequences for the mother and baby. The root cause of preeclampsia is an unhealthy placenta which releases toxins into the maternal blood causing maternal organ damage. This project will identify early pregnancy biomarkers to detect women who are at risk of developing preeclampsia and discover the key molecular mechanisms which drive preeclampsia
column3: leading to new preventative treatment options."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019925^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019925"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Metformin
column2: gut epithelium and microbiome in the prevention of colorectal cancer
column3: Ideas Grants"^"Prevention of colorectal cancer (CRC) saves lives. Metformin
column4: a safe drug clinically used as an anti-diabetic therapy
column5: has been shown to suppress cancer. Yet
column6: its successful implementation as a CRC preventative is limited by a lack of knowledge on how metformin elicits these anti-cancer effects. Our project will provide a holistic understanding of how metformin impacts the colon lining
column7: its microbiome and CRC development."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019931^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019931"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The first tool to quantify brain copper during life
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Copper is essential for brain health but serious diseases result from either too much
column3: or too little
column4: copper in the brain. Unfortunately we do not have a method to measure brain copper levels. This limits our ability to understand the role of copper in these disorders and to deliver safe
column5: effective treatments to patients. We are developing a technology to directly measure brain copper levels during life to solve these important problems."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019934^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019934"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Novel determinants of male fertility carried by seminal fluid extracellular vesicles
column2: Ideas Grants"^"A father's influence over reproductive outcome goes beyond the provision of sperm. Our research has shown that signals carried by seminal fluid influence the likelihood of conception and pregnancy
column3: but the identity and regulation of these signals is unknown. This research will define novel drivers of fertility and expand our understanding of the biological events at conception. Ultimately
column4: these findings will inform the development of therapeutics that address the rising burden of infertility."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019948^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019948"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Harnessing a native corticosteroid-binding globulin to treat life-threatening septic shock
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Septic shock is a maladaptive response to overwhelming infection that leads to organ failure and death. Corticosteroid-binding globulin (CBG) is a blood protein with unique properties to deliver the body’s natural anti-inflammatory hormone
column3: glucocorticoid
column4: to threatened organs - but its excessive depletion in septic shock triples the risk of dying. Our experiments in mouse models of sepsis are important next steps towards the use of CGB therapy to prevent deterioration and death in patients."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019968^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019968"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Developing Therapeutic Engineered Virus-Like Particles to Target Genetic Diseases of the Retina
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Inherited retinal disease is a leading cause of blindness among working-aged adults. Advances in diagnosis have identified mutations in genes which can cause these diseases. The project aims to develop and construct personalised gene therapy treatments for patients with inherited retinal diseases. The team will combine customised gene editing tools to fix their particular gene mutation together with a delivery system that specifically target the affected cell type."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019970^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019970"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The neural bases of inhibitory learning and disorders of action control
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Several mental disorders including Tourette syndrome and obsessive-compulsive disorder
column3: share a common feature
column4: that is
column5: the repeated urge to engage in behavioural sequences that are counterproductive or damaging. This proposal will study the neural bases of naturally-occurring processes for behaviour change by which subjects learn to inhibit maladaptive actions. The findings will help develop effective therapeutic interventions that promote inhibitory learning in affected individuals."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019988^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019988"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A human experimental model to assess whether the gut microbiota regulates specific and non-specific immune responses to vaccination
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Our hypothesis is that the gut microbiota is a critical and targetable factor regulating specific and non-specific immune responses to vaccination. To assess this
column3: we will investigate the impact of depleting the human gut microbiota on protection mediated by the BCG vaccine against microbes specifically targeted by the vaccine and unrelated infections. This study will lead to new interventions to maximise vaccine mediated protection in vulnerable populations worldwide."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019991^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019991"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Transforming the management of perinatal depression through precision medicine to improve outcomes for women and children
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Pharmacogenetics have increasingly been shown to be relevant to the understanding of outcomes associated with antidepressants. By using a study of 862 women
column3: including 158 taking antidepressants in pregnancy
column4: we propose to use a new novel approach to elucidate how better to manage depression in pregnancy for women and also predict vulnerability to adverse impacts for the infant following antidepressant exposure and whether this can be attributed to variation in pharmacogenetics."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019993^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2019993"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Tuning mitophagy in mitochondrial diseases
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The accumulation of damaged mitochondria is detrimental to cells and results in diseases. This fundamental research addresses how cells maintain a healthy mitochondrial population. We have discovered a pathway that maintains healthy mitochondrial numbers in cells. This pathway does not function properly in a devastating disease called mitochondrial DNA depletion disease. In this proposal
column3: we seek to determine strategies to restore mitochondrial function in this disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020010^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020010"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Let there be light- Modified Serpin as a Dual Function Therapeutic Agent in Glaucoma
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Glaucoma causes blindness and despite our best treatment many patients continue to progress. A new and innovative approach is needed to protect the cells that die in the retina. We have engineered a protease inhibitor – neuroserpin – a protein that is deactivated in the disease. We aim to deliver this molecule to retinal cells using an “artificial virus” approach and determine its usefulness as a novel and innovative therapy in glaucoma."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020020^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020020"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A novel approach to reducing the psychosocial burden of infertility treatment
column2: Ideas Grants"^"One in six Australian couples experience infertility. Up to 75% of patients will report anxiety or depression during reproductive treatment
column3: but less than 20% will receive mental health support. This research will generate new evidence on how coping
column4: social support and mood change across an in vitro fertilization cycle (IVF). It will produce an online coping intervention for patients and information resources for partners and families
column5: leading to better mental health outcomes after IVF."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020035^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020035"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Computational analysis and Artificial Intelligence in brain tumour imaging: towards the augmented diagnostics of the future
column2: Ideas Grants"^"This work will apply computer models
column3: including Artificial Intelligence techniques
column4: to augment expert diagnosis of brain tumours with the aim of better predicting patients’ prognosis
column5: optimising their treatment and thereby improving their outcomes. By the end of this research
column6: a new diagnostic paradigm will be in place: computers will help clinicians and surgeons in their decision-making to ensure the best treatment of patients affected by brain tumours
column7: throughout their journey."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020050^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020050"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A Fat Chance for Melanoma
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Recently a study in melanoma patients showed that overweight patients did much better on treatment than normal weight patients. This project aims to understand how body fat makes melanoma patients more responsive to therapy. By understanding the biological basis for this association
column3: we can design new therapeutic strategies that will improve the outcomes for melanoma patients and not lead to adverse health effects associated with being overweight."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020077^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020077"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Using genomic signatures of natural selection to elucidate the genetic architecture of multiple sclerosis
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Multiple sclerosis (MS) is more common in people of European descent
column3: and more common further from the equator. It is likely that this pattern has been shaped by natural selection. Identifying genes that increase MS risk and have experienced natural selection will improve our understanding of what causes the disease. We will identify specific genes that are under local selection in response to environmental factors
column4: helping to better target therapies aimed at these risk factors."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020078^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020078"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"New ways to treat fatty liver disease: a focus on lipid metabolism
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Individuals with obesity have increased risk of developing other metabolic diseases including non-alcoholic fatty liver disease and diabetes. This is partially due to impairments in the capacity to burn fat and excessive accumulation of fat in most tissues of the body. We have identified a new pathway by which cells of the body regulate fat breakdown. In this project
column3: we aim to test whether activating this pathway is effective in slowing the development of fatty liver and diabetes."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020097^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020097"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Unlocking the Therapeutic Potential of a New ‘Dual-Action’ Target for Bone and Joint Diseases
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Diseases affecting the bones and joints are devastating to physical function and human health and often feature bone destruction by osteoclasts
column3: giant bone dissolving cells. However
column4: treatments for these diseases remain inadequate. We have discovered a new molecule that blocks osteoclast function and helps build new bone when inhibited. This proposal evaluates the utility of this promising target for the development of new bone preserving drugs for the treatment of bone and joint diseases."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020111^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020111"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Predict
column2: prevent and treat bone metastases in prostate cancer
column3: Ideas Grants"^"Bone metastases are a fear development of prostate cancer that cannot be predicted and for which there is no effective treatment. In this translational and multidisciplinary project
column4: we will develop an innovative strategy to predict
column5: prevent and treat bone metastases. Our idea is based on cancer neurosciences and the targeting of nerves in prostate cancer."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020113^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020113"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Network level decoding of touch and pain in the spinal cord
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Understanding how touch and pain signals pass through the spinal cord is critical in pain treatment
column3: especially for touch-evoked pain. Our current understanding focuses on small circuits of spinal nerve cells
column4: even though we know touch and pain activate much larger networks to produce signals that reach our brain. This project will decode network-level signalling of touch and pain in the spinal cord by studying activity in large nerve cell networks using imaging and complex systems analysis."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020121^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020121"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Test often
column2: treat early: Are major changes in policy and practice needed to eliminate hepatitis C among people with HIV?
column3: Ideas Grants"^"Hepatitis C treatment is highly effective
column4: preventing liver-related morbidity and mortality for individuals
column5: as well as onward transmission of hepatitis. However
column6: current limitations on the number of tests per year and restrictions on treatment until chronic hepatitis C infection has been confirmed
column7: mean that treatment is usually delayed for over a year after diagnosis. This proposal aims to estimate potential benefits from allowing more frequent testing and earlier treatment."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020137^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020137"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"In vivo genetic engineering of T-cells for cancer treatment using novel exosome mimetic nanoparticles
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Despite the promise of using genetically engineered T-cells for treatment of a variety of immune-mediated diseases
column3: current methods are expensive
column4: labour-intensive
column5: result in significant side effects
column6: and have limited availability. In this proposal
column7: we will re-engineer naturally occurring vesicles that are present in our body to allow them to redirect T-cells to specific danger signals. We will examine the therapeutic efficacy of this novel nanotechnology in cancer."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020149^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020149"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Spatial analysis to investigate cancer evolution as a complex ecosystem of interacting tumour populations
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Cancer is a disease where cells grow rapidly
column3: creating tumours. However
column4: all tumour cells are not the same. There can be multiple cell types within a single tumour. These are likely interacting
column5: helping each other grow. We aim to understand which tumour cells are cooperating with each other in prostate cancer that has spread using computational methods. With this
column6: we hope to develop a new type of treatment that works by disrupting how tumour cells talk with each other and thus kill tumours."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020151^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020151"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Development of new treatment options for post-sepsis acute lung injury (ALI).
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Acute lung injury (ALI) occurs due to uncontrolled inflammation and is a major cause of death in Australia because there are no treatments. We recently found treatment with a new protein called A3 protects mice from this condition. In this project
column3: we will develop A3 into a new class of anti-inflammatory drug and test it in mouse models of ALI that resemble human ALI and validate our results in human cells. This invention will address one of the most important unmet clinical needs worldwide."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020152^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020152"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Autoimmunity; Finding the key to chronic atherosclerotic inflammation and plaque rupture
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Heart disease is the leading cause of death globally
column3: and ~1/3 of all deaths in Australia. Inflammation has been identified as a major cause of heart disease. However
column4: what drives inflammation in heart diseases is not well known. Our research will explore how T cells
column5: a common white blood cell
column6: might cause heart attacks and strokes. By doing so
column7: we will identify new ways in which we can treat inflammation and thereby prevent the massive numbers of deaths caused by heart disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020164^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020164"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Assessment and modulation of cortical sensorimotor control for recovery after stroke
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Our goal is to promote the recovery of motor function after stroke. We will create a computational model of the effects of stroke on the motor control system throughout rehabilitation. We will determine whether electrical stimulation can enhance the effect of movement-based therapy on recovery after stroke. We will also adjust our stimulation based on ongoing brain activity. We hypothesise that feedback mediated rehabilitation is a more robust mechanism to activate affected areas."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020169^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020169"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Protecting vitamin D levels to prevent chemotherapy-induced gastrointestinal mucositis
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Vitamin D deficiency is common in cancer patients
column3: and is linked to the incidence of many cancers. Maintaining vitamin D levels is key for maximising therapeutic outcomes and preventing chemotherapy- induced mucositis. We will identify cancer patients as ‘at risk’ for vitamin D deficiency
column4: leading to higher incidence and severity of chemotherapy-induced mucositis. We will investigate therapeutic options for maintaining vitamin D levels and preventing chemotherapy-induced mucositis."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020173^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020173"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Bacteriophages: a new paradigm in caring for infected wounds.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"We will develop wound dressings carrying bacteriophages (viruses that kill bacteria) as a safe
column3: effective way to treat wound infections. This will have great impact on treatment of diabetic foot ulcer infections
column4: which currently often lead to amputation
column5: which carries extremely high mortality. This work will lead to a new paradigm in wound care and will dramatically improve the lives of people with diabetes."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020185^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020185"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"An accessible chronic pain therapeutic target in peripheral sensory nerves
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Chronic pain is hugely debilitating and its prevention remains an area of unmet clinical need. Nerve injuries result in exaggerated responses to painful
column3: and even mild
column4: stimuli. In pre-clinical models
column5: we have discovered that removing a single protein from neurons
column6: either throughout the nervous system or only in the peripheral nervous system
column7: significantly diminishes injury-induced pain. This research aims to find a way to interfere with the development of chronic pain by targeting this protein."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020192^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020192"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Using Big Data to Engineer Highly Immunogenic Hepatitis C Virus Envelopes for the Induction of Broad Neutralising Antibodies
column2: Ideas Grants"^"There is an urgent need to develop a preventative vaccine against hepatitis C
column3: a virus that causes chronic life-threatening disease in millions of people globally. This project will bring together intelligent big data design methods and innovative experimental models to engineer panels of viral antigens for eliciting antibodies capable of neutralising diverse virus strains. The findings can be used to design new hepatitis C vaccines aimed at preventing virus infection and chronic disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020197^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020197"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A Bioengineered Model of Calcific Aortic Valve Disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Calcific aortic valve disease is a common cause of mortality and morbidity in the elderly. Our limited knowledge of the mechanisms that drive the progression of aortic stenosis is a major obstacle in developing medical treatments for this disease. This project utilises a bioengineered aortic valve model that mimics features found in the early and late stages of this disease. It enables the systematic study of the complex pathology of this disease and serves as a platform for screening drugs."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020226^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020226"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Understanding neurodegeneration caused by oligodendroglial dysfunction
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Globular glial tauopathy (GGT) is a recently described frontotemporal dementia
column3: a debilitating early-onset neurodegenerative disorder. GGT is characterised by abnormal tau protein in oligodendroglia
column4: the main neuron support cell. Previous research has focused on neurons
column5: which cause neurodegeneration and clinical symptoms with little consideration of oligodendroglia. This study will investigate how dysfunction in oligodendroglia causes neurodegeneration in human and preclinical disease models."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020234^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020234"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Community driven communication and engagement during health crisis periods: co-designing enhanced and transferable strategies
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Communicating crisis information with “hard-to-reach” culturally and linguistically diverse (CALD) communities is a significant challenge. Leveraging existing networks and actors can ensure that information reaches CaLD communities. We will fill a key gap via developing a: (1) communication and engagement strategy that outlines best practices around the identification and support of information intermediaries and (2) a training program that focuses on capacity building with CaLD communities."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020251^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020251"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A Systems Genetics Approach to Defining the Sexual Dimorphism in Exercise-Induced Cardioprotection
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Men and women differ in their risk and development of cardiovascular disease (CVD) and their response to the protective effects of exercise; however
column3: we do not fully understand the mechanisms underlying these differences. We propose to generate a cutting-edge research tool that characterises the changes in the heart at rest and in response to exercise in male and females. Using this tool
column4: we will identify novel targets that we will test for their ability to treat CVD in a personalised manner"^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020253^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020253"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The Burning Question – how safe is sun exposure at low-dose and intensity?
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Skin cancers are more common in Australia than all other cancers combined. To reduce their burden
column3: Australians are advised to protect their skin when the sun is strong
column4: but not when the sun is weak. We will test whether low-intensity sunlight is ‘harmless’ by exposing the skin of volunteers to non-burning doses of UV radiation
column5: and then assessing the effects on their skin cells. The information from these experiments will inform sun protection policies."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020285^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020285"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"New approaches to enhance immunotherapy for brain tumours
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Primary brain tumours and brain metastases arising from other tumours both have extremely poor patient outcomes. Immunotherapy offers great promise for brain tumour therapy
column3: but is currently limited due to brain tumour-induced immunosuppression. This proposal aims to overcome this problem to improve the potency of brain tumour immunotherapies. Successful outcomes in this work have the potential to dramatically improve the survival outcomes for glioblastoma patients."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020289^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020289"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Modulation of the M4 muscarinic receptor for the treatment of schizophrenia
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The M4 muscarinic receptor is a promising drug target for treating schizophrenia
column3: with therapeutic outcomes above and beyond any current antipsychotics. Recently
column4: two M4-targeting drugs
column5: xanomeline and emraclidine
column6: have progressed to advanced stages in clinical trials. This project aims to explore the pharmacological outcomes of xanomeline and emraclidine as a novel
column7: first-in-class
column8: dual therapy to ultimately assist in designing more effective and safer drugs for treating schizophrenia."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020303^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020303"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Exploiting GPX2 deficiency to enhance radiation response in gastrointestinal cancers
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Bowel cancer is a major global health problem. Here
column3: we will investigate how loss of protein called GPX2 can on the one hand contribute to the development of this disease
column4: but make cancers sensitive to radiotherapy on the other. By studying the role of this critical protein
column5: this project will deliver important new knowledge into how colorectal cancers arise
column6: enable us to identify patients most likely to benefit from radiotherapy
column7: and to develop a new way to improve response to this treatment."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020305^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020305"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"HARNESSING TUMOUR SPECIFIC HOMING AND EVOLUTION OF PROBIOTIC BACTERIA TO ENGINEER NEXT-GENERATION BOWEL CANCER TREATMENTS
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Bowel cancer kills over 5000 Australians each year. This failure of current treatments shows that a very different approach is needed. We are investigating the use of probiotics engineered to selectively release drugs direct to tumours. This research will help us understand why the probiotics home to tumours and how they change once in the tumour
column3: so that we can better design probiotic treatments to treat bowel cancer in the future."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020315^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020315"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A novel algorithm for accurate and efficient alignment of long DNA and RNA sequencing reads
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Long-read sequencing is a new development in DNA/RNA sequencing. It helps to find mutations and other genomic features that can never be found before. Mapping read sequences to the genome is usually the first step in the analysis. We will use many novel concepts to develop a new tool for long-read mapping. Because of its high efficiency and accuracy compared with the current tools
column3: it can strongly enhance the value of long-read sequencing in both research and clinical settings."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020316^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020316"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Dissecting the role of group 2 innate lymphoid cells in gastric cancer
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Gastric inflammation and early gastric cancer (GC) development elicits a rapid expansion of specialised immune cells (ILC2) in the stomach and their dissemination into the bloodstream. This project aims to uncover the impact of the systemic spread of ILC2s on metastatic niche formation and metastatic cancer growth in the context of aggressive GC and to investigate the utility of circulatory ILC2 as diagnostic biomarker for GC in order to achieve better health outcomes."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020334^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020334"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Functional impact of CTCF binding site mutations in 3D cancer genome regulation
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Understanding what regulates gene expression in normal cells and how this goes wrong in cancer is still one of the biggest challenges in modern biology. This grant is focused on investigating two classes of non-coding somatic mutations in breast and prostate cancer
column3: which we hypothesise disrupt binding of an important DNA regulator (CTCF) and results in deregulation of specific regions of gene expression. Unravelling mechanisms underpinning CTCF site mutations may lead to new cancer treatments."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020371^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020371"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A novel molecular test to determine if a pathogen is alive or dead - a tool to transform infectious disease management and reduce the threat of antimicrobial resistance
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Antimicrobial resistance is threatening our ability to treat infections globally. Current molecular tests for infectious disease detect both living and dead pathogens contributing to overdiagnosis and treatment. We will use a novel real time molecular assay
column3: adaptable across pathogens
column4: to determine what proportion of sexually transmitted infections are viable as an exemplar. This study could transform our entire public health approach to infectious disease diagnosis and antimicrobial stewardship"^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020376^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020376"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Improving therapeutic responses in oesophageal cancer by overcoming resistance to ferroptosis
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Compared to normal tissues
column3: oesophageal cancers increase their consumption of nutrients from the surrounding environment and change the way they use these nutrients in order to survive
column4: grow
column5: spread to other organs and resist treatments. This project will identify which nutrients oesophageal cancers depend on to survive
column6: and develop strategies to exploit these dependencies and improve the efficacy of treatments used to combat this disease
column7: thereby improving cure rates and long term outcomes."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020377^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020377"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Elucidating the signalling functions of Transmembrane Pseudokinases as a strategy to develop novel therapeutics modalities
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Cells require highly coordinated communication signals to grow and divide. Any improper signalling responses can lead to conditions
column3: such as cancer and inflammation. Pseudokinases have recently been discovered to play a vital role in the coordination of signals that can lead to cancer. This program aims to elucidate how transmembrane receptor pseudokinases contribute to “out of control” signalling
column4: which will provide novel therapeutic strategies to counteract pseudokinase-driven diseases."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020421^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020421"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Overcoming antiseptic and disinfectant resistance in staphylococci
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Strains of Staphylococcus aureus (Golden Staph)
column3: resistant to almost all available anti-staphylococcal agents
column4: are responsible for serious infections among patients. Resistance has emerged to all classes of antimicrobial agents
column5: including antiseptics and disinfectants. We will increase our understanding of proteins that confer resistance by pumping multiple compounds out of the cell to ultimately be able to block their action."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020423^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020423"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Harnessing the protective effects of Interferon epsilon as a therapeutic for endometriosis
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Endometriosis is a chronic
column3: debilitating condition that affects 1 in 9 menstruators. People with the disease have limited treatment options and there is no cure. A defective immune response is one of the causes of the disease. This project aims to investigate a new immunomodulator
column4: interferon epsilon (IFNe)
column5: which may exert protective effects against the development of endometriosis. We will investigate whether IFNe can be used as an innovative treatment for endometriosis."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020434^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020434"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A human brain organoid model of acute prenatal hypoxia enables biomarker discovery and drug screening for hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"A lack of oxygen supply to the baby before and during birth has devastating immediate and long term consequences for brain development. Quantifiying the severity of birth asphyxia in newborns is difficult
column3: little is known about the molecular and cellular processes involved
column4: and effective treatments beyond cooling the newborn do not exist. Here we will use innovative human brain organoid models to address and overcome each of these knowledge and capability gaps."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020443^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020443"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Engineered Amphiregulin: A Novel Growth Factor to Promote Tissue Regeneration
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Tissue regeneration is facilitated by key proteins that are released by immune cells in injured tissues. These proteins include growth factors
column3: which are promising drugs for regenerative medicine. However
column4: growth factors have found limited clinical success due to poor efficacy and/or side effects. We have developed a novel engineered growth factor that shows significant promise in promoting tissue healing. This project will confirm its safety and efficacy for regenerative medicine applications."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020452^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020452"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting interleukin-18-mediated inflammation to treat advanced kidney disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Kidney failure is a leading cause of death and morbidity worldwide. This project will use state-of-the-art technologies to characterise the role of a newly identified molecule (interleukin-18) that contributes to the pathological remodelling that precedes kidney failure. The therapeutic potential of interleukin-18 inhibition will also be tested. This research will define an entirely new mechanism of kidney disease and validate interleukin-18 as a target for new therapies."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020453^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020453"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Nuclear mechanobiology in cell migration and metastasis
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Preventing
column3: diagnosing
column4: and treating metastasis (the appearance of secondary tumors within the body) is the key to reducing death in breast cancer patients. Yet we still do not know exactly how cancer cells leave their tumors and invade into blood vessels to metastasise. Here we will test a new idea that invading breast cancer cells control their genes differently to normal cells
column5: by the cell sensing its environment. This new understanding will help develop new drugs and diagnostic tools."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020454^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020454"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Stratifying low-calorie sweeteners for diabetes risk
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Low calorie sweeteners are not inert sugar supplements. Rather
column3: they are emerging as a risk factor for the development of diabetes. They can enhance sugar absorption from the gut and disrupt bacteria that live there
column4: which can raise blood sugar levels. However
column5: sweeteners are all distinct and are likely to affect blood sugar differently. We will test these differences in innovative human and animal studies to identify which sweeteners are safer options
column6: in an effort to prevent type 2 diabetes."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020455^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020455"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"CRACing the role of the Flavivirus NS1 protein
column2: Ideas Grants"^"In this proposal
column3: we will investigate the mechanisms by which various forms of the dengue viral protein
column4: NS1 physically interacts with lipids and cholesterol. This is a critically important interaction for efficient viral replication and so understanding the ways in which NS1 engages with these host cell components should provide important clues as to how we can disrupt this interaction and so design potential anti-viral strategies not only for dengue
column5: but also other flaviviruses."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020482^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020482"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Viral modulation of the host cell: The STAT3 Interface
column2: Ideas Grants"^"This project will examine how viruses that cause major human diseases are able to interact with and control the cells that they infect
column3: specifically through targeting of a central cellular regulator protein called STAT3. We will examine precisely how viruses selectively regulate STAT3 to control multiple processes in our cells that support viral infection and spread
column4: and hence disease. By understanding how viruses do this
column5: the project will identify new potential strategies to combat infections."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020483^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020483"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Discovery of eosinophil-derived thermogenic beiging factors to combat obesity
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Obesity is a global problem. We study the signals that control the switch between the accumulation and the burning of fat. A new type of fat
column3: beige fat
column4: is important in burning rather than storing fuel. Our data show that signals from a specialised immune cell – the eosinophil – convert normal fat into beige fat. By identifying the signaling molecules eosinophils produce in mouse and human tissue
column5: we seek to mimic their action
column6: and therapeutically stimulate beige fat to combat obesity."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020501^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020501"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Comparative human functional genomics of Island Southeast Asia
column2: Ideas Grants"^"To date nearly all studies of how DNA variants impact genes have been carried out in people of European descent. But insights gained from them do not always translate to other populations. By combining measurements of gene expression obtained at a single cell level with samples from Island Southeast Asia
column3: this project will be the first to characterise the genetic differences that impact immune response in these populations
column4: with implications for disease progression and personalised medicine."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020517^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020517"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Examining the ‘how’ and ‘why’ of blood cell gene regulation at loci relevant to autoimmune disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Every person has a distinct DNA code
column3: which is why some people get certain diseases and some don’t. This code is complex and we currently only understand a fraction of what it does. Our research aims to understand which bits of DNA code are important for causing autoimmune diseases. We will do this using new technologies
column4: like subtly changing the DNA code and looking at the effect this has. Understanding how these changes influence disease can benefit clinical diagnosis and drug development."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020532^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020532"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"New pooled CRISPR screening approaches to study pain and painful venoms
column2: Ideas Grants"^"It is time to develop new
column3: effective
column4: and non-addictive ways to manage pain
column5: but this can only come from a better basic understanding of pain biology. Here
column6: we develop and apply new pooled CRISPR screening technologies to map the human genome for factors that control pain. Our work here will yield the first genome-scale basic understanding of human pain regulation
column7: and will provide a foundation for rational new painkillers for the 21st century."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020540^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020540"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Hypothermic machine perfusion of circulatory death hearts for transplantation
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Novel technology has been developed to mitigate injury associated with heart preservation during heart transplantation. Preliminary studies show this technology is effective
column3: but its beneficial effects are poorly understood. This project will investigate at a functional and cellular level how this technology improves heart function during heart transplantation. Increasing use of this technology will increase the donor heart pool
column4: and decrease the risk of death following heart transplantation."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020543^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020543"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Characterising a novel molecular pathway to reduce penicillin failure for Strep throat
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Strep throat is a common bacterial infection caused by Group A Streptococcus (GAS). While GAS is sensitive to penicillin in vitro
column3: 10-20% of infections recur after treatment. We have identified that some GAS strains can replicate in a penicillin-resistant intracellular niche. This project will define this mechanism of resistance to penicillin and other antibiotics
column4: and develop a prototype test to detect resistant infections at the point of care. This will lead to better treatment outcomes."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020555^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020555"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"HORIZONTAL GENE TRANSFER TO DETECT MUTATION AND REACT TO COLONIC NEOPLASIA
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Bowel cancer is common and is defined by changes to our genetic material (DNA). In this project we will answer whether bacteria that naturally live in the bowel can be coerced to take up cancer DNA through cutting-edge synthetic design; and whether bacteria could
column3: in the future
column4: detect and then react to bowel polyps and cancer and thus facilitate the detection
column5: prevention and treatment of bowel cancer."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020562^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020562"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"PRC-1 regulation of mature CD8+ T cell effector and memory responses
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The programming of effective killer T cell immunity is associated requires appropriate gene regulation that ensures acquisition of the specific functions necessary for control of infection and cancer
column3: as well as the establishment of effective immunity. This study will examine how a key factor called PRC1 regulates the induction of optimal protective virus and tumour T responses. This knowledge will contribute to the development of novel treatments for infection
column4: cancer and autoimmune disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020563^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020563"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The influence of genetic variation on foetal alcohol spectrum disorder
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Drinking alcohol during pregnancy is the most common cause of environmentally induced human birth defects. But there is not a simple linear relationship between the amount of alcohol ingested and the consequence for the unborn child. In this research we will examine how the genetic makeup of an unborn child influences the consequence of maternal alcohol consumption."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020565^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020565"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Therapeutic targeting of TLR7 in autoimmunity
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Autoimmune diseases
column3: which are driven by self-reactive autoantibodies
column4: affect approximately 5% of all Australians. While treatments are available to limit disease progression and morbidity
column5: these are non-curative and can have numerous harmful side-effects. Here
column6: we propose an innovative approach to thwart autoimmune disease by targeting how autoantibodies are generated. We have developed a new class of specific therapeutics that have the potential to help treat diverse autoimmune conditions."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020567^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020567"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Reverse translation of a rodent cognitive flexibility task
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Cognitive dysfunction is prominent in patients with neuropsychiatric and neurodegenerative disorders
column3: yet current treatments have little effect on these symptoms. We need better treatments
column4: but this requires better testing protocols. The goal is to provide a novel cognitive flexibility task for cognitive research in rodents that will help to develop initiatives to prevent
column5: treat and rehabilitate patients with cognitive impairment."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020569^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020569"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Liver metastases: a niche of resistance and of therapeutic opportunities for all cancers.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Drugs that stimulate immune cells to fight cancer (immunotherapy) have been used in melanoma and other cancers. The majority of melanoma patients resistant to immunotherapy have their melanoma spread to the liver; and we will study the effect of the presence of liver metastases on the immune response
column3: in order to unveil novel mechanisms of resistance and therapeutic targets. Given the global finding across other cancers
column4: our work has potential for impacting a broad range of cancer patients."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020579^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020579"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A novel pharmaco-genetic treatment for auto-immune kidney disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"There is mounting evidence that the enzyme DNase I is a novel non-toxic therapeutic for autoimmunity
column3: an appealing alternative to long-term use of current sub-optimal immunosuppressive drugs that carry significant toxicities. This project will build the translational bridge for application of a “one shot” DNase I therapy in humans with autoimmune kidney disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020587^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020587"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A novel proinflammatory mechanism reveals an innovative therapeutic strategy to treat hepatic inflammation in chronic liver disease.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"We have generated considerable evidence for a role for tissue ferritin as a mediator of inflammation associated with liver fibrosis (scarring). These highly novel and innovative studies will identify the mechanisms associated with H-Ferritin-regulated liver inflammation in hepatic stellate cells (scar-forming cells in the liver) in chronic liver disease
column3: which we will use to develop novel anti-inflammatory therapeutics to inhibit inflammation and fibrosis associated with chronic liver disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020590^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020590"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Incubation of craving for alcohol: Is exercise a viable intervention?
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Environmental cues elicit strong craving in people with alcohol use disorder. These cravings increase over longer periods of abstinence
column3: in many cases prompting relapse. In a preclinical model
column4: we have found that increased compulsion to seek alcohol across abstinence can be prevented with voluntary exercise. In this project we will identify the neural changes responsible for both the increase in craving and the restorative effect of exercise
column5: and test the longevity of exercise benefits."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020606^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020606"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Monoclonal antibodies to placental malaria antigen VAR2CSA
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Placental malaria parasites express VAR2CSA protein on the red blood cell surface. From the blood of pregnant women with strong antibody to VAR2CSA
column3: we will isolate antibody-producing B cells. We will test the antibodies produced by the B cells to find antibodies which can block placental infection
column4: can clear or kill infected cells
column5: and react with many strains. The best ones will be tweaked to further improve activity. Optimised monoclonal antibody to VAR2CSA may prevent placental malaria."^""^""^""^
