column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020613^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020613"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Dissecting the regulatory mechanisms controlling antigen processing and presentation in dendritic cells
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Dendritic cells of the immune system utilise specific receptors to sense danger signals from their environment. We identified a DC danger receptor
column3: Clec9A
column4: which recognizes and induces immunity to “dangerous” dead cells eg. infected cells. We will investigate how dendritic cells regulate their responses to “dangerous” dead cells
column5: and the checkpoints that control immune responses. We will use this knowledge to develop novel approaches for vaccines and immunotherapies for improved health outcomes"^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020624^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020624"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Inhibition failure in Alzheimer’s disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Dementia is a leading cause of death in Australia with a huge socioeconomic burden. Network of the brains executive cells
column3: the neurons
column4: are critical for the normal function of the brain. We hypothesize that distinct populations of neurons are compromised or lost in dementia brains
column5: resulting initially in mild cognitive impairment and progressing to severe dementia. This project aims at understanding how these network fail and will test novel way to prevent or treat the resulting deficits."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020626^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020626"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Co-designing a consumer-focused digital health system to improve adverse drug event (ADE) detection
column2: management and reporting
column3: Ideas Grants"^"Medicines have many benefits
column4: but can also cause harm. Currently the effects of medicines and any potential harms are not monitored for the majority of people taking medicines. This project will develop a new digital health system that enables consumers and health professionals to actively detect medicine harms
column5: and to report the harms to the medicine regulatory authority in Australia. We will also develop new tools to better communicate medicine safety issues to the public."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020633^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020633"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The use of Pro-apoptotic Drugs to Eliminate HIV in the Brain
column2: Ideas Grants"^"HIV affects >37 M people worldwide and no scalable cure exists. Current approaches to cure HIV utilises drugs that are designed to target and kill HIV-infected cells in the blood. However
column3: the efficacy and possible toxicity of these compounds in the brain is unclear. Our study will use novel animal cohorts and human brain cells to determine the ability of these drugs to target and kill HIV-infected cells in the brain
column4: thus
column5: informing on the suitability of these drugs in people with HIV."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020636^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020636"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"What Matters to First Nations Kids: Co-designing a wellbeing measure for First Nations children aged 5-11 years (WM2K Project)
column2: Ideas Grants"^"This project gives First Nations Australian children the chance to have a say about what is important to their wellbeing. The project team will engage First Nations children and their primary carers from across the country to co-design a new wellbeing measure that asks questions about what makes a good life for them. The measure will be widely available for use by decision makers to better understand the real impacts of policies and programs to improve the lives of all First Nations children."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020646^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020646"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Molecular mechanisms underlying NF1 dysfunction in tumour growth and disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Mutations of the neurofibromin tumour suppressor gene cause the common genetic disease neurofibromatosis type 1 and drive numerous cancers including melanoma
column3: breast and brain cancer. We will apply new breakthrough technologies to uncover how the neurofibromin protein is dysregulated at the atomic level and inside the cell. This project will discover new pathways for therapeutic intervention for Australians living with NF1-linked disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020732^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020732"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Next generation technology for paediatric blood pressure monitoring
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Blood pressure (BP) monitoring is critically important in hospitalised children and in those with hypertension
column3: but is impeded by low tolerance to repeated cuff inflation. In this project
column4: a novel cuffless BP device suitable for children will be developed and tested in real clinical settings. The device will overcome the distress and sleep disturbance caused by current devices
column5: enabling more reliable and timely identification of high or low BP levels that can cause permanent brain/kidney damage."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020737^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020737"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting Bromodomain and Extra-Terminal (BET) Proteins for Preventing Preterm Birth
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Preterm birth is the biggest contributing factor to death and disease among newborns. This application explores the physiological mechanism that controls pregnancy length and is disrupted in preterm birth. We focus on the involvement of key regulatory proteins that can be targeted by drugs and will determine the potential of these drugs to block preterm parturition."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020743^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020743"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"How is immunogenic double-stranded RNA regulated in cells?
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Fundamental to a functional immune system is the ability to correctly distinguish between material from our own cells and from a virus. Failure to do so results in auto-inflammation. We have identified three new genes that are important for regulating virus-like RNA in our own cells
column3: to prevent inflammation. Understanding these genes provides crucial insights and potential new therapeutic targets for diverse settings from auto-inflammatory disease to cancer
column4: viral immunity and RNA therapeutics"^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020750^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020750"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Translating and field-validating an epigenetic blood test to predict TB infection and disease risk
column2: Ideas Grants"^"We will deliver a validated DNA blood test which can be used to identify asymptomatic individuals in at-risk communities who are infected with the tuberculosis bacteria and at risk of developing symptomatic disease over 3 years. Community screening asymptomatic individuals with this test has the potential to have the greatest impact on reducing TB cases
column3: by allowing us to better target preventative therapy to those most in need
column4: before they develop disease and transmit the bacteria to others."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020757^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020757"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting hepatic amino acid transport to combat cardiometabolic disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The overarching idea of this proposal is to find a way to mimic the health benefits of dietary protein restriction while avoiding negative health consequences. To this end
column3: we have invented a way to internally mimic a protein restricted state
column4: and preliminary data have shown that such a strategy can reduce cardiometabolic disease biomarkers. This proposal seeks to thoroughly understand and to provide key evidence of the effectiveness of this novel drug target against cardiometabolic disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020758^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020758"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A novel dual therapy approach to treatment of multidrug-resistant Gram-negative infections
column2: Ideas Grants"^"This project will use multiple advanced approaches to pinpoint how new derivatives of the anticoccidial drug robenidine kill and exert their specific activities against different superbugs. This study is of utmost significance in the current era of inexorable rise in multidrug resistance. The project will generate critical data that will promote targeted and responsible use of new antimicrobials
column3: in alignment with similar global approaches towards eliminating multidrug resistance development."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020762^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020762"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Striatal population involvement in OCD symptom domains
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD) is associated with disturbances in different areas of flexible behaviour
column3: including flexible actions (compulsions)
column4: threat responses (obsessions) and decision making. The striatum is a brain region that is critical for flexible behaviour
column5: and that is also over active in OCD. The current proposal will determine how the two distinct functional neural populations in the striatum contribute to different disturbances in flexible behaviour relevant to OCD."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020768^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020768"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A new mechanism for targeting stress-related mental health disorders
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Australians have faced significant emotional trauma over the past two years. Unfortunately
column3: treatments for stress-induced psychiatric illness remain poor. By establishing a causal role of hypothalamic PVN-CRH cells in stress-induced psychopathology independent of the stress hormones
column4: these studies will significantly shift the current dogma in psychiatry
column5: leading to new studies and therapeutic opportunities for the treatment of stress-related disorders including depression and PTSD."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020780^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020780"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Does finite slowing of feeding cause artemisinin resistance in malaria?
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Drug resistance to the frontline antimalarial artemisinin is a major challenge to addressing the global burden of malaria. Deteriorating artemisinin resistance could lead to this drug becoming unusable
column3: or could be manageable if drug resistance doesn't worsen and spread. We have determined the mechanism that underlies resistance and will test whether this is a finite and manageable process or instead is an escalating system that likely presages worsening prospects for global artemisinin use"^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020782^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020782"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Optimising sleep quality inside insecticide treated mosquito nets in hot overnight environments
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Nine-five percent of all Malaria transmission occurs within the African region
column3: causing approximately 600 000 deaths per year. Insecticide-treated bed nets are one of the primary interventions used to stop the spread of malaria. However
column4: sensations of feeling too hot to sleep comfortably is the primary reason for not using bed nets. By simulating real-world conditions
column5: this project will determine how fans can be used to improve thermal comfort and sleep quality within the bed net enclosure."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020814^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020814"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Identification and functional characterisation of genomic enhancers in the human brain: a steppingstone to clinical translation of genetic data for brain disorders.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The genetic basis of brain disorders is incompletely understood. An important discovery over the last decade was that genetic variants associated with brain disorders are likely to impact gene expression regulation. The proposed project studies enhancers
column3: the key regulatory elements of the genome that turn genes on and off. The project aims to identify enhancers that play functional roles in brain cells
column4: thereby uncovering how genetic changes lead to brain disorders."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020822^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020822"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"4D molecular characterisation of C-RIP proteins required for malaria host-cell entry
column2: Ideas Grants"^"We have identified proteins that control the dynamic release of essential antigens required for malaria parasite infection of host red blood cells and will identify druggable interactions between these proteins that can be targeted to kill malaria."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020851^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020851"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting sympathetic nerves to treat metastatic triple negative breast cancer
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Survival from metastatic triple negative breast cancer is terrible. Our new findings suggest that nerves within cancers undermine the beneficial effects of current treatments. This project investigates how blocking nerves improves response to treatment
column3: and will determine how to optimally apply these findings so cancer patients benefit."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020861^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020861"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"New approaches to treating hemoglobinopathies
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The genetic disorders ß-thalassemia and sickle cell disease are caused by mutations in the adult globin gene. Fortunately
column3: humans have a second globin gene
column4: the fetal globin gene
column5: which is expressed in utero but turned off after birth. Re-activating expression of this fetal globin gene can alleviate the symptoms of ß-thalassemia and sickle cell disease. We are using new strategies
column6: including sophisticated gene editing
column7: to boost fetal globin output to treat this disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020900^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020900"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"RNA-mediated regulation of chromatin compaction in development and disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Polycomb repressive complexes are enzymatic complexes that safeguard the genome by preventing repressed genes from becoming active. The proposed study aimed at identifying how RNA regulate certain types of polycomb repressive complexes to maintain genes in a compacted state that prevent their expression. The project aims to determine how RNA regulates the formation of compact chromatin structure and to visualize this process in high resolution."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020902^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020902"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Designing novel blood and MRI-based predictive tools to understand disease mechanisms
column2: improve recovery and guide targeted interventions following neonatal arterial ischaemic stroke
column3: Ideas Grants"^"Around 120 Australian babies suffer a stroke every year but causes are unknown. Almost half experience long-term problems such as cerebral palsy
column4: speech
column5: learning or behavioural difficulties. The study aims to answer the two most important questions that parents ask their doctors: why did my baby have a stroke and how will the stroke affect my baby’s future development? We will do this by looking at blood signatures and use advanced MRI imaging to study brain networks in 50 babies with stroke."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020911^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020911"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting the 4Ms in cancer treatment – matrix
column2: mechanics
column3: microenvironment
column4: metabolism
column5: Ideas Grants"^"This project addresses a clinical problem with an innovative approach. Pancreatic cancer is one of the deadliest cancers and only 10% of patients survive 5 years after diagnosis. To find better therapies
column6: we need patient-specific models that mimic the biology of tumour tissues and target interactions between different cell types. We will develop a controllable platform for modelling the human disease in the laboratory. We will use our new platform to discover better ways of treating the disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020950^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020950"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"High-throughput ex vivo screening of human retinal cell specific delivery nanoparticles for gene therapy
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Using nanoparticles as carriers of therapeutic payloads is one promising way to treat retinal diseases. They can carry significantly larger payloads than viruses. The project combine single-cell RNA sequencing with a barcoded library to perform high-throughput screening for the nanoparticles that will cell-specifically deliver genes. These identified carriers will be used as vectors to introduce the gene constructs or drugs specifically into the target retinal cells to treat retinal diseases."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020961^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020961"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting IL-6 trans-signalling in brain injury
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Acquired brain injury is a leading cause of ongoing disability worldwide. Although the damage caused by the primary insult is irreversible
column3: a series of secondary events cause further nerve cell death and exacerbate brain dysfunction. My laboratory has recently uncovered a way to prevent these secondary events by targeting the brain’s immune cells - microglia. Here we will dissect as to how microglia can be manipulated to promote repair following brain injury."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020984^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020984"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Identifying endometriosis risk and disease variability by mapping endometrial stem cell maturation
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Endometriosis is a poorly categorised disease. Diagnosis is via surgery and patient outcomes are varied. Identifying markers for disease risk and sub grouping would greatly improve treatment for individual patients. Endometriosis grows from endometrial stem cells that enter the peritoneal cavity. We identified altered differentiation increases endometriosis risk and propose to identify factors that cause altered differentiation and the biological signatures that result to improve treatment."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020999^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020999"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Neuroprotective benefit and safety of preterm neonatal sulphate supplementation
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Preterm babies become sulphate deficient after birth
column3: increasing the risk of cerebral palsy. Any intervention that prevents cerebral palsy in preterm infants
column4: particularly a simple
column5: low-risk
column6: low-cost intervention would have considerable personal and economic benefits. In this study
column7: we will investigate the impact of sulphate supplementation on brain development in preterm piglets
column8: which will help develop future sulphate therapies in human preterm infants."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021009^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021009"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting desmoglein-2 to reinvigorate anti-tumour immunity
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Pancreatic cancer and melanoma are amongst the deadliest forms of cancer which continue to rise in prevalence. Despite clinical advances
column3: once metastasised
column4: cancer from any organ is universally fatal. The growth and spread of solid tumours requires access to the blood supply as well as control of the immune response. Our work on tumour vasculature
column5: in these most difficult to treat tumours
column6: has identified an adhesion protein on the cancer cells that may help fight this deadly disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021010^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021010"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Muscle-directed gene therapy as an adjuvant to neuroprotection: Targeting both ends of the dysfunctional nerve-muscle axis to treat motor neurone disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis involves nerve cell death and deterioration of the muscles that the nerves control. Effective treatments are lacking. Capitalising on our team’s complementary expertise in neuroscience and muscle physiology
column3: we are developing a multimodal treatment strategy designed to protect nerves and promote muscle re-growth. Targeting both ends of the ‘nerve-muscle axis’ will prevent premature death of people with this disease and stimulate functional recovery."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021029^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021029"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Enabling remote screening of childhood hearing loss using artificial intelligence
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Children born in Australia are tested to check if they have a hearing loss. This newborn screening doesn't pick up some forms of hearing loss and can't detect a hearing loss that only appears later in life. This project will create a smartphone app parents can use to record their child speaking to check if they may have a hearing loss. The app will provide a simple way for parents
column3: health workers
column4: and teachers to help make sure all children with hearing loss are diagnosed as soon as possible."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021041^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021041"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Exploiting sex differences in androgen action to advance a novel treatment for breast cancer.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"We have recently discovered that activation of the androgen receptor (AR) can redirect the cancer-promoting activity of the estrogen receptor (ER) to halt rather than promote breast cancer growth. The current study will establish if AR activating drugs influence the immune system to inhibit growth of ER-driven breast cancers to establish androgen therapy as a more effective treatment strategy."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021055^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021055"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Reducing the burden of respiratory distress after caesarean delivery.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Compared with vaginally born babies
column3: babies born at term by caesarean section have a higher risk of needing intensive care due to breathing problems soon after birth. We have recently made a major break-through in understanding why and this project will provide the additional information required to identify effective treatments for these otherwise healthy newborns. Ultimately this research will identify approaches and treatments that will reduce the risk or severity of this breathing problem."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021057^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021057"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"SETDB1 Epigenetic checkpoint blockade: A new approach to enhance immune-mediated control
column2: Ideas Grants"^"SETDB1 is a novel drug target that mediates immunotherapy resistance. We have shown that the nuclear form of SETDB1 is enriched in tissue and blood samples from immunotherapy-resistant metastatic cancers. We have designed a new drug targeting nuclear SETDB1 (MSETC) that targets both cancer cells and simultaneously re-invigorates the immune system. In this project
column3: we will undertake critical molecular pre-clinical studies towards advancing our prototypic drug (MSETC) to the clinic."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021063^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021063"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Understanding and targeting self-renewal in aggressive blood cancers
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The epigenetic protein Menin
column3: is critical for the ability of leukaemia cells to divide indefinitely. Therapies that target this protein are currently in clinical trials
column4: however it is unclear how they work. By studying how resistance to these therapies emerges
column5: we have unexpectedly discovered that they work differently to what was previously thought. This proposal will use new tools to elucidate these findings in order to develop ways to overcome resistance and improve their efficacy."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021074^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021074"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Organ Transplantation as a Model of Reversible Frailty
column2: Ideas Grants"^"People with end-stage kidney failure often have low energy and muscle weakness. Clinically
column3: they are “frail”. Since health status improves significantly post-transplant
column4: organ transplantation is a model of reversible frailty. In this study
column5: we’ll measure frailty and biological data in 3 groups: (1) people before and after a kidney transplant (2) people with kidney failure who don’t receive a transplant (3) older people who are frail. This will provide new insights into the causes of frailty."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021082^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021082"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Defining the features of atypical T cell responses in Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) controllers
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) directly attacks our immune system
column3: impairing our natural defence against infection and disease. HIV has infected ~76 million individuals worldwide
column4: leading to a long-lasting pandemic with no vaccine or cure currently available. However
column5: there are rare individuals able to control HIV infection. Our work focuses on understanding how these individuals’ immune system can control HIV
column6: thereby aiding the design of novel treatments or potential vaccines against HIV."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021085^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021085"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Modelling of mitochondrial disease in specific cell lineages to understand pathomechanisms and develop effective targeted therapies
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Mitochondrial disorders are a group of inherited diseases that can cause severe
column3: life-limiting disease in at least 60 children born in Australia each year. These disorders impact on the brain
column4: heart and other organ systems and we lack effective treatments
column5: partly because we don’t understand the disease mechanisms. We will use human cell model systems
column6: including stem cells differentiated into heart cells
column7: to study disease mechanisms and trial new treatment approaches."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021126^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021126"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Reversing Neurofibrosis: A New Way to Treat Type-2 Diabetes
column2: Ideas Grants"^"We aim to discover new treatments for type-2 diabetes (T2D)
column3: a national and global health priority. Brain cells that maintain blood glucose levels within a safe range
column4: are encased within a specialised extracellular matrix. We have discovered that this matrix becomes augmented and defective in T2D
column5: a process termed neurofibrosis. Neurofibrosis makes neurons insulin resistant
column6: which results in high blood sugar levels. We will pioneer the very first drugs targeting neurofibrosis to treat T2D."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021130^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021130"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Improving HPV vaccine rates for Aboriginal young people through social media
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Human papillomavirus (HPV) is a common sexually transmitted infection that can lead to HPV-related cancers. HPV rarely produces symptoms and cannot be cured or treated; therefore
column3: vaccination is essential to protect against HPV and HPV-related diseases. This project aims to improve HPV vaccination rates amongst young Aboriginal people. Our project will combine health messages co-created by young people and implemented by micro-Influencers to improve HPV vaccination."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021155^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021155"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Investigating the morphological and molecular origin of non-compaction cardiomyopathy
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Every year
column3: 1 in 100 Australian babies are born with heart malformations of a genetic origin stressing the need for further research. In this project
column4: we will investigate one of the most recently classified genetic cardiac condition and therefore
column5: one of the least understood. Our expert team will apply innovative approaches to better understand the condition and provide crucial insights to design customized genetic screening panels and treatments for patients suffering from this disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021163^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021163"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting Endosomal Receptor Signalling for Superior Pain Relief
column2: Ideas Grants"^"G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are important drug targets. A key feature of GPCR function is their ability to internalise when stimulated
column3: and it is now appreciated that this can promote signalling events that are uniquely associated with diseases of global relevance
column4: including chronic pain. This project will define signalling processes mediated from internalised GPCRs
column5: and develop nanomedicines for targeted delivery of drugs to specific sites inside cells for superior pain relief."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021172^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021172"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Indigenous telomere-2-telomere human reference genomes to enable discovery
column2: translation and innovations
column3: Ideas Grants"^"Our project will use the latest DNA sequencing technologies to generate
column4: for the first time
column5: indigenous telomere-2-telomere reference genomes. These genomes will account for ancestral diversity and underpin the implementation of precision medicine
column6: enable discoveries and drive innovations using genomics. Critically
column7: the project will foster existing and create new partnerships with Indigenous communities through mutually agreed benefits of the genomics revolution."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021176^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021176"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The neuroprotective potential of exercise in individuals with motor neuron disease - a paradigm-changing idea
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Every day two Australians die from motor neuron disease (MND) - an incurable neurodegenerative disease. This project aims to discover if exercise can slow neurodegeneration in MND. Thanks to the interdisciplinary expertise of our international consortium
column3: we will investigate the neuroprotective potential of exercise on the brain
column4: spinal cord
column5: and muscle of patients with MND. This research has the potential to change the role of exercise in the treatment of MND."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021181^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021181"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Unravelling tumour plasticity via parallels with tissue regeneration
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Development of resistance to chemotherapy is a major challenge in the treatment of bowel cancer. We are exploring whether a new cell type that is produced when the lining of the gut is injured
column3: is also produced as bowel cancers acquire drug resistance. We will characterise these cells and examine if approaches directed at targeting these cells are capable of eliminating bowel cancers. This work could provide a rational basis for the design of new combination treatments for bowel cancer."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021182^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021182"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Unravelling the brain-lung communication pathway as a novel way of improving stroke outcome
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Lung infection is highly prevalent and often deadly in patients with stroke
column3: raising the possibility of weakened antibacterial responses in the lung after stroke. The focus of this project is to investigate the mechanisms underlying impaired lung immunity following stroke onset. We will also assess the potential of exosome content as biomarkers to identify high-risk stroke patients who will require antibacterial therapy to limit infection development and improve patient outcomes."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021183^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021183"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Fluent Mobility for the Blind Individual Using Multimodal Auditory Sensory Augmentation
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Fluency in blind users' mobility arises from access to an appropriate flow of sensory information
column3: subtle control over the sensory information flow
column4: and natural interaction. Any unimodal sensory augmentation system will fail to provide sufficient fluency
column5: therefore we propose a multimodal sensory augmentation system using smart glasses and gesture control to improve fluency in mobility and orientation for blind individuals."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021186^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021186"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Developing and applying a world-first alcohol market monitoring system
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The alcohol market is evolving rapidly
column3: with new products being brought to market and creative marketing strategies being implemented
column4: often targeting younger drinkers. This project will deliver a world-first system of monitoring marketplace changes and providing timely data to policy makers to enable them to implement effective policy responses. A sustainable system of product monitoring and data reporting will be delivered to assist with alcohol harm-reduction strategies long term."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021208^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021208"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"UNIVERSAL NEUROPHOTONIC INTERFACE: A REVOLUTION IN MEDICAL BIONICS
column2: Ideas Grants"^"This project aims to deliver the proof-of-concept of a universal nerve interface
column3: which eventually will bidirectionally connect any bionic device to the peripheral nervous system. This would allow the brain to directly control any bionic device and also to receive sensory feedback
column4: i.e. to “feel”. We will achieve this by combining permanently photoactive neurons
column5: located on pre-determined areas on a photonic chip and addressed by light. Their axon will form a nerve-like structure."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021218^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021218"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A Faster Cure for Tuberculosis: Revealing Adjunctive Antimicrobial Solutions
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The world urgently needs effective solutions for TB
column3: a bacterial infection that claims more lives than any other. We have identified a "weak link" in the defences of the bacteria responsible and aim to find ALL such vulnerabilities
column4: enabling the development of the next generation of therapy for TB. We will identify ways to weaken these bacterial defences
column5: enhancing potency of existing antibiotics
column6: and rescuing antimicrobial resistance
column7: delaying the need for development of new TB antibiotics."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021228^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021228"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Making next-generation dendritic cell vaccines a reality
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Dendritic cells (DCs) kickstart the immune response to fight infections and cancer. Considering their power
column3: they are also being harnessed for immunotherapy for use as ‘DC vaccines’ for the treatment of solid cancers and other immune disorders. We have found a novel way to make DCs in a petri dish in the large amounts required for such an approach. If we can demonstrate this approach is feasible in mice
column4: it will provide the impetus to seek translational studies for use in humans."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021247^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021247"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Understanding non-genetic inheritance in health and disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Eggs provide genetic and non-genetic (epigenetic) information that is critical for offspring development. While we understand how genes transmit instructions that regulate offspring development
column3: epigenetic inheritance is poorly understood. This project will determine how an essential epigenetic mechanism acting in eggs controls formation of tissues in offspring and grand-offspring and how dysregulation of this mechanism results in disease. Outcomes will help understand disease inheritance."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021260^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021260"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Investigating the application of targeted therapeutics for the treatment of complex lymphatic vascular anomalies
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Complex lymphatic anomalies arise due to defects in the development of lymphatic vessels during embryogenesis and result in stillbirth or chronic disease. We have identified pathogenic variants in the MDFIC gene underlying a complex lymphatic anomaly termed CCLA. Here
column3: we will investigate the signalling pathways affected by pathogenic MDFIC variants and determine whether small molecule inhibitors of these signalling pathways might provide novel therapeutics able to effectively treat CCLA."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021267^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021267"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Antibody based therapeutic development for coronaviruses
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The first human coronavirus was isolated from individuals suffering from the common cold in the 1960’s. Since then
column3: three highly pathogenic human coronaviruses have arisen in the last two decades; SARS in 2002
column4: MERS in 2012 and the devastating COVID-19 pandemic. It is critical we understand how current and emerging coronaviruses infect humans and more importantly
column5: develop therapeutic agents to tackle current disease
column6: resist future SARS-CoV-2 variants and new coronavirus-origin pandemics."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021271^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021271"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Structurally informed vaccines and therapies to resist and counter JEV emergence
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Flaviviruses such as JEV are arthropod-borne human pathogens that infect over 200 million annually. The current JEV vaccines are based on >50 year old strains
column3: raising the question of whether these are still optimal against modern emerging strains including the recent Australian outbreak. In this project we will reveal the molecular differences that define JEV strains. This will provide framework for a new generation of JEV vaccines as well as identify new antivirals to treat JEV infection."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021272^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021272"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Dissecting the mechanisms of flavivirus neuro-pathogenesis using the systems biology approach
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Flaviviruses are important pathogens that Include West Nile
column3: Japanese encephalitis and Zika viruses. They can infect human brain causing severe neurological diseases. This project is aimed to identify the cells in the brain vulnerable to viral infection and elucidate the molecular processes affected by the viruses in the brain. This will explain why flaviviruses cause neurological disease and identify the molecules that can be targeted to prevent or mitigate infection in the brain."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021286^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021286"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Medulloblastoma plasticity
column2: persistence
column3: relapse and resistance
column4: Ideas Grants"^"Childhood cancer is devastating. For young children with medulloblastoma the outlook is bleak and if the cancer comes back after treatment it is lethal. We will identify cancer cells that survive treatment with a new drug
column5: Palbociclib
column6: and show how they lead to relapse. We will find out if the presence of these cells predicts relapse in patients
column7: and develop a map of how cells develop tolerance to the drug that will help us to identify ways we might target these cells to prevent relapse."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021290^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021290"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Functional genetic screen of osteoclasts targeted to risk loci for osteoporosis
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Numerous genetic risk variants for osteoporosis
column3: which have been identified through genome-wide association studies and are specifically relevant to osteoclast function
column4: have been partially characterised by our group. We will now use targeted Perturb-seq
column5: which involves pooled CRISPR screens that couple targeted genetic perturbations relevant to the risk loci
column6: with single-cell transcriptomics of the osteoclasts to definitively delineate the mechanism of effect of the variants."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021292^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021292"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Selective Modulation Of Brain Circuits In Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a mental illness that can be very difficult to treat and causes significant disability and suffering. In this research
column3: we plan to understand how focussed electricity delivered through permanent stimulating electrodes (deep brain stimulation) works in the brain to treat OCD and how we can translate this knowledge into new therapies that can be used without the requirement for surgery - thereby increasing acceptability and accessibility for more people."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021305^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021305"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Bioengineering of next-generation adeno-associated viral vectors for gene therapy clinical applications using whole human liver explant preclinical model
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The recent exciting advancements in gene therapies targeting genetic conditions of the liver
column3: eye and brain rely on viral vectors that enable delivery of the therapeutic cargo to the targeted cells. Unfortunately
column4: vector utilised for therapeutic delivery to human liver lack in efficacy
column5: which increases therapeutic cost and lowers safety. Most advanced preclinical model of human liver
column6: the human liver itself
column7: will be used to develop the next generation of vectors for clinical implementation."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021307^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021307"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Modulators of T cell signaling: mechanism of pathogen virulence factors and design of synthetic immunomodulatory constructs
column2: Ideas Grants"^"T cells are immune cells critical for clearing infections and fighting cancer. They can distinguish healthy from infected or cancerous cells by sensing cues in their environment and encoding this information into networks of biochemical reactions
column3: which are integrated into a functional decision. We will use cutting edge microscopy techniques to decode this information processing mechanism so that we may better intervene when T cells make incorrect decisions and fail to perform their function."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021322^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021322"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Improving CNS copper availability to mitigate permanent neurological disability in progressive cases of multiple sclerosis
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The accumulation of permanent neurological disability in progressive cases of multiple sclerosis represents a major
column3: unmet medical need. New treatment options are required
column4: but their production to date has been limited by incomplete knowledge of the underpinning biological factors and events. This application presents our discovery of a treatable feature of progressive multiple sclerosis and outlines our plan to develop novel compounds that can produce life-changing outcomes."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021360^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021360"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A gut feeling about new therapies for glioma treatment: lessons from the enteric nervous system
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Gliomas are the most aggressive form of brain cancer. Gliomas come from glial cells
column3: a type of support cell in the nervous system. Glial cells are found in the brain and also in the enteric nervous system
column4: which is located in the gut. However
column5: gliomas are rarely found in the gut and are generally benign. In this study
column6: we aim to identify factors that protect enteric glial cells from forming aggressive cancers in order to develop new treatments for brain cancer."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021380^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021380"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Protecting hearts from trastuzumab-induced cardiomyopathy
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Heart failure is a serious side-effect of an antibody-based therapy for breast cancer. The antibody targets a growth receptor called HER2
column3: which is also present in hearts cells where it is critical for normal cardiac structure/function. We propose to mutate the HER2 receptor so it is no longer recognised by antibody
column4: but where it retains functionality. In a mouse model of Herceptin-based cardiac toxicity
column5: we will use viruses to deliver the resistant HER2 receptor to heart and rescue function."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021396^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021396"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Genomic Autopsy of Pregnancy loss Study (GAPS): genomic investigations to help solve unexplained pregnancy loss at all gestations.
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Despite scientific and medical advances
column3: the rate of miscarriage and stillbirth has not declined in Australia over the past 20 years. Our project aims to better understand the underlying causes of pregnancy loss across all gestations. We will use novel genomic techniques and for the first time study variation in the placenta that may contribute to pregnancy loss. Accurate diagnosis is essential for counselling
column4: and offers families reproductive choices to avoid future recurrence."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021404^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021404"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Pregnancy and early life virome dynamics: contribution to chronic diseases
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Viral infections during pregnancy and early life can majorly impact on maternal and infant health
column3: and cause lifelong health issues
column4: especially among those at risk of chronic disease. However
column5: little is known about the early life virome of Australians
column6: and whether it is a risk factor for pregnancy complications and chronic diseases. We will use the most comprehensive
column7: sensitive and unbiased methods to assess pregnancy/early exposure to all viruses and their association with chronic diseases."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021463^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021463"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Targeting novel cellular protagonists of cardiac fibrosis
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Heart failure is a leading cause of death. We have recently discovered two new heart cell types that emerge after cardiac stress to drive fibrosis—a key precursor for the development of heart failure. This project aims to determine what genes support the development of these cells and whether targeting these cells prevents the development of fibrosis after cardiac stress. This project may reveal novel approaches to prevent or treat heart failure by targeting these new fibrosis-promoting cells."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021475^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021475"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Understanding novel ways that bacteria drive virulence by subverting metal ion intoxication
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The pathogen Group B streptococcus (GBS) is a significant risk to human health
column3: an ageing Australian population and is a major cause of severe infections in babies. This project will define fundamental aspects of streptococcal biology
column4: revealing how bacteria survive in the human body. The outcomes will highlight novel strategies for disease prevention and treatment. Ultimately
column5: this work could reduce the economic and social burdens imposed by GBS infections on our healthcare."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021495^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021495"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A neural metabolic memory of diet restriction influences rebound weight gain
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The overconsumption of high calorie foods in today’s society is a primary reason for the obesity epidemic. In this proposal we argue that periods of repetitive hunger program a metabolic memory of food shortage
column3: which exacerbates feeding responses
column4: motivation and food reward
column5: especially high energy foods. A strong metabolic memory of food shortage may precipitate compulsive overeating
column6: which is a major cause of obesity in today’s society."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021510^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021510"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Exploring the anti-apoptotic and apoptosis-unrelated functions of MCL-1 during embryonic and blood cell development to advance MCL-1 inhibitors in clinical trials for cancer
column2: Ideas Grants"^"In a healthy organism damaged or autoreactive cells kill themselves by a controlled cell death program
column3: called apoptosis. Pro-survival proteins (e.g. MCL-1) block apoptosis
column4: and their enhanced expression causes cancer. Some pro-survival inhibitory drugs (e.g. Venetoclax) are effective and well tolerated
column5: whereas the highly effective MCL-1 inhibitors cause intolerable side effects in clinical trials. This project aims to determine the differences of these proteins to improve cancer therapy."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021525^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021525"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Defining the mechanisms that underpin the environmental contribution to Parkinson’s disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The number of people with Parkinson’s disease (PD) is doubling every 20 years as a consequence of exposure to environmental stressors from an industrialised world. These stressors increase the risk of developing PD
column3: however
column4: the underlying biology is poorly understood limiting our ability to intervene. We will characterise the link in this pathway and its association with PD. This knowledge will enable us to develop new intervention strategies that can attenuate the rising incidence of disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021560^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021560"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Predicting disease progression in patients with myeloid neoplasms to enable early intervention
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Myelodysplastic and myeloproliferative neoplasms (MDS/MPN) are blood cancers with multiple genetic mistakes that have a risk of progressing to acute myeloid leukaemia (AML)
column3: a rapid and fatal disease. There are no reliable approaches to predict who is going to develop AML. Based on the idea that a skewed hormone receptor is the cause of the problem we propose to identify its genetic fingerprint that can predict when MDS and MPN will transform to AML to enable faster and better treatments."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021564^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021564"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Unveiling the modulators of scarless wound healing
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Aberrant wound healing
column3: scarring and fibrosis results in a tremendous burden on public health to treat or have them surgically removed. After injury a fibrin clot forms
column4: this project aims to understand the properties of fibrin clots
column5: that drive scarless
column6: as observed in foetuses
column7: or positive wound healing outcomes. Then engineer these key properties into smart fibrin biomaterials to improve the management of injuries to promote scarless wound healing to improve patient outcomes."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021586^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021586"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Optimising treatment of Hepatitis B with novel predictive biomarkers
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Hepatitis B is treatable but most people have to take medicine for life. Some people can safely stop treatment after a few years but it is difficult to predict for each person whether or not the virus will come back. We have developed a new test to measure different forms of virus in the liver. This test should identify people who can safely stop treatment and those who need to continue. In this grant we will study how to use our test to improve quality of life for people living with hepatitis B."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021587^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021587"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Combining multi-omic causal-prediction networks from large patient datasets with a human intestinal organoid pipeline to identify new therapies for IBD
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Inflammatory Bowel Diseases are an increasingly prevalent cause of morbidity worldwide. Therapies that induce mucosal healing are a key unmet clinical need required to improve disease remission. Using a form of artificial intelligence on genomic networks from large patient datasets we have identified novel drug targets in the intestinal epithelium. In this project we will use human 'mini-guts' to investigate the potential of these drug targets to improve healing and reduce disease severity."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021595^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021595"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Sleep Disruption and Alzheimer’s Disease Pathology – Investigating Mechanisms via Acoustic Stimulation of Slow Wave Sleep
column2: Ideas Grants"^"A change in the sleep-wake system
column3: particularly reduced deep sleep
column4: is associated with impaired memory and cognition
column5: and other aspects of brain health in later life. We will use exciting new technology and never-before-used ways of understanding the brain to reveal the causal role of deep sleep in brain and cognitive health. This will provide critical evidence for the use of sleep therapeutics which increase deep sleep to enhance brain health and promote cognition in older adults."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021623^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021623"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Sensitivity to BH3 mimetics identified by BCL2 family interactions
column2: Ideas Grants"^"BH3 mimetics are small molecule therapeutics which have resulted in paradigm shifts in the management of several cancers
column3: although they are not curative and patients inevitably develop resistance. The mimetics bind to prosurvival BCL2 family members and displace proapoptotic members
column4: indicating that sensitivity can be predicted by measuring complexes formed by BCL2 members. This project will develop the first antibodies to those complexes to measure responses of cancer cells to BH3 mimetics."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021638^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021638"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"A genomics-powered ultrahigh-throughput pipeline for rapid antibiotic discovery
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Antibiotic resistant bacterial infections are becoming increasingly common in both hospitals and the community. A key strategy to overcome resistant bacteria is to identify new antibiotics. However
column3: we must do this faster and more creatively or we risk rediscovering already known antibiotics. This project will miniaturise and accelerate the antibiotic discovery process
column4: allowing us to investigate previously unseen bacteria and find antibiotics to combat multi-drug resistant infections."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021644^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021644"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Genomic medicine for Indigenous Australians
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Whole genome sequencing of individuals from four remote Indigenous communities uncovered genomic patterns that suggest why previous studies failed to identify the genetic basis of two important diseases. We will use this information to develop a novel approach to find the causes of chronic kidney disease in people from the Tiwi Islands. These genetic patterns also allow us to recommend guidelines that increase the chance of success for future mapping projects in other Indigenous communities."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021675^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021675"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Harnessing Endogenous Opioids to Treat Gut Motility Disorders and Pain
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Opioids are highly effective pain killers and anti-diarrheal drugs
column3: but their use can be severely limited by serious side-effects. An alternative therapeutic strategy that largely avoids these side-effects is to harness the actions of opioids produced by the body. This project explores a new approach to enhance the effects of these opioids to provide natural pain relief and a new approach to regulate the movement of contents through the intestine."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021687^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021687"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Blocking harmful lung damage during acute exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) caused by infections
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) affects over 2 million Australians and acute attacks
column3: triggered by viruses or bacteria
column4: can be fatal. Standard treatment with steroids is highly damaging to the lungs and safer treatments are urgently needed. Our team of leading clinical and basic science COPD researchers has identified a new drug with the potential to improve patient outcomes. Our pioneering studies will break the connection between COPD attacks
column5: infections
column6: lung damage and death."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021704^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021704"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Mechanisms of regulatory T cell function
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Normal regulation of the immune system is vital to human health
column3: especially after bone marrow transplantation
column4: but we still do yet not know exactly how it is achieved. In this project we will study one of the most important molecules used to regulate immune responses
column5: CTLA-4. We aim to show that secreted CTLA-4
column6: rather than CTLA-4 on the surface of immune cells
column7: is responsible for immune regulation. Secreted CTLA-4 may hold promise as a new therapy for graft-versus host disease after transplant."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021732^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021732"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The Development of splice-switching oligonucleotides for the management of kidney disease
column2: Ideas Grants"^"RNA can now be used to treat human diseases. It can be used as a template to make a new protein
column3: such as in mRNA vaccines. But RNA can also be used change how coding elements are spliced together and the protein that results from them. This strategy has been used to great effect in difficult-to-treat diseases like muscular dystrophy and spinomuscular atrophy. We will apply this same technology to target pathways critically involved in the development and progression of chronic kidney disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021749^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021749"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Pre-emptive targeted therapy to optimise high-risk neuroblastoma treatment
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Despite intensive and prolonged treatment
column3: half of all children diagnosed with high-risk neuroblastoma either do not respond
column4: or subsequently relapse. There are no curative therapies for these patients. Current approaches are clearly inadequate for these children
column5: and experimental therapies are being introduced too late. This study aims to change this paradigm through comprehensive pre-clinical evidence supporting earlier intervention with targeted agents."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021763^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021763"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"What codes the development of asthma in children?
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Wheezing in children is very common. At present
column3: we cannot predict which young children who wheeze will progress to develop the lung disease asthma. Thus
column4: we cannot prevent asthma and treatment for asthma is broadly the same for everyone. We will analyse skin cells from inside the nose and blood cells from children who wheeze. Changes in these cells will help predict who will go on to develop asthma. Better
column5: more specific treatments can also be developed."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021811^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021811"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Wnt Signalling in Oligodendroglia: A missing link in MS neuroinflammation
column2: Ideas Grants"^"Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is a disease in which a person’s immune system incorrectly attacks a specific group of cells within the central nervous system (CNS) called oligodendroglia. Destruction of these cells causes neurodegeneration that leads to devastating functional deficits. Oligodendrogila have the capacity for regeneration
column3: but it is insufficient. We aim identify new therapeutic targets that boost the ability of oligodendroglia to regenerate and thus limit the neurodegneration in MS."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021864^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2021864"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Establishing caffeine as a potential new treatment option for circadian misalignment
column2: Ideas Grants"^"The aim of this project is to examine the effects of caffeine on the human internal body clock. In particular
column3: we will assess the extent to which a moderate amount of caffeine
column4: equivalent to a double-shot espresso
column5: can shift the timing of the body clock. The results of this project will enable practitioners to use caffeine to treat disorders and behaviours that seriously disrupt the body clocks of 20% of Australian adults (e.g.
column6: delayed sleep onset
column7: night work
column8: international flight)."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022034^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022034"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Development of bivalent degraders targeting Aurora kinase A for the treatment of polycystic kidney disease
column2: Development Grants"^"Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) affects >1:1000 people and is a leading cause of kidney failure. There are no useful treatments. We have shown this disease is driven by a protein called AURKA. We have discovered a drug candidate that potently degrades this disease-driving protein in cells. This grant will support development of potency and selectivity to give a patented drug candidate for a potential safe and effective treatment for ADPKD."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022040^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022040"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Development of a New Class of Formyl Peptide Receptor 1 (FPR1) Biased Agonists for the Treatment of Myocardial Infarction
column2: Development Grants"^"Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of death
column3: accounting for 30% of all global deaths. We have discovered a highly potent and novel compound that is unique in boosting a particular signalling pathway in heart tissue that can greatly improve recovery from heart attack
column4: but this compound needs further optimization of properties that will enable it to be taken as a pill. This Development Grant will resource optimization of this novel drug candidate for the treatment of heart attack."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022050^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022050"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Breaking drug resistance in community-acquired bacterial pneumonia (CABP)
column2: Development Grants"^"There is an urgent and critical need to develop new ways to treat infections caused by drug resistant bacterial pathogens (superbugs). Our new therapeutic approach using an antibiotic potentiator is an entirely new strategy to disrupt the antibiotic resistance mechanisms of multidrug-resistant bacteria. Our treatment using the antibiotic potentiator renders drug-resistant superbugs sensitive to existing
column3: frontline antibiotics and will restore the efficiency of existing treatment regimens."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022057^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022057"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"StandingTall: Digital Fall Prevention Solution
column2: Development Grants"^"Falls in older people worldwide are common
column3: with one in three older people experiencing one or more falls per year. StandingTall is a tailored and progressive digital exercise program designed for older people to do at home by themselves. We will leverage the experience and intellectual resources of leading industry providers and consumers using a co-design partnership approach to ensure the successful commercialisation and implementation of StandingTall into clinical practice."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022075^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022075"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Mechanistically and chemically novel reaction-hijacking pro-inhibitors for malaria
column2: Development Grants"^"Diseases caused by drug-resistant infectious agents
column3: such as the malaria parasite
column4: represent an enormous global health threat. New drugs are desperately needed to overcome drug resistance. We have discovered a new "Trojan horse" method to induce malaria parasites to make their own toxic molecules – making them the instruments of their own demise. In this project we will work with a major pharmaceutical company toward developing these new therapeutics."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022121^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022121"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Developing a new type of drug for inflammatory lung disease
column2: Development Grants"^"Millions of Australians have breathing difficulties due to viral/bacterial infections or environmental allergens/pollutants (dust mites
column3: pollen
column4: food
column5: smoke) that trigger inflammation leading to lung disease (e.g. asthma
column6: COPD
column7: fibrosis). We have discovered a new type of drug that blocks inflammation in human cells and damage in mouse models of lung disease. This study can improve drug potency
column8: selectivity and effectiveness and provide proof of concept preclinical data to enable clinical trials."^""^""^""^
