column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022218^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022218"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Development of a novel optical stimulation therapy for Obstructive Sleep Apnoea
column2: Development Grants"^"Obstructive sleep apnoea is a common sleep disorder where the upper airway collapses repeatedly during sleep
column3: interrupting breathing. It is associated with accidents and elevated risk of cardiovascular disease. Current treatments are poorly adhered to by patients
column4: and there is a substantial market for new therapies that are patient-friendly. This project aims to bring a new minimally invasive light-stimulation therapy
column5: Optosleep
column6: to the stage where it can be tested in human patients."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022337^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022337"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Hybrid 3D-printed imaging catheter for more accurate cardiovascular disease detection
column2: Development Grants"^"Most heart attacks are caused by high-risk plaques. A significant unmet need in cardiology is to reliably detect high-risk plaques before they are life-threatening. This project will deliver the first-in-human study and commercialisation of our novel hybrid 3D-printed imaging catheter. This novel device is likely to enable accurate detection of high-risk plaques and prevent (recurrent) heart attacks. This high-tech device is ideal for manufacturing in Australia and has great export potential."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022449^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022449"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Development of nanomedicine for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis
column2: Development Grants"^"Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) is a leading cause for liver cancer. The failure of promising drugs is due to their inability to address all aspects of this complex disease. In this proposal
column3: we provide compelling evidence that nanoparticles shed by amniotic epithelial cells (a perinatal stem-like cell) have multivalent properties in the context of NASH. We propose the development of these ‘amniotic exosomes’ as a regenerative medicine for NASH."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022583^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022583"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"EarGenie: A diagnostic system to transform the management of infants with hearing loss
column2: Development Grants"^"After an infant is diagnosed with a hearing loss via new-born screening
column3: it is critically important that a hearing aid or cochlear implant is provided as soon as possible: otherwise language development is significantly and permanently impacted. In this project we develop a novel hearing assessment system that will reduce the delay between diagnosis and provision of the optimal hearing solution for each infant from 9-24 months down to 2-6 months
column4: thus leading to improved quality of life."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022585^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022585"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Development of novel GPR52 agonists for the treatment of schizophrenia
column2: Development Grants"^"We are developing a novel class of drug candidates as better treatments for schizophrenia
column3: a debilitating psychiatric disorder. Current therapeutics address only one component of the disorder and cause significant side-effects
column4: often leading to discontinuation of treatment. There is a well-recognized and significant unmet need for novel
column5: effective treatment options with fewer side effects that also address the negative symptoms and cognitive impairments core to schizophrenia."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022625^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022625"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Development of a therapeutic monoclonal antibody
column2: Development Grants"^"This project specifically relates to the development of a product - a humanised monoclonal antibody. The project has now reached an early proof-of-principle-stage of product development and represents a highly promising commercial opportunity for Australia
column3: with annual sales of monoclonals exceeding $100 billion in 2021. To be able to progress our basic discoveries into a commercial product a humanised antibody is required."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022635^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022635"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Splice switching oligonucleotides for the treatment of chronic kidney disease
column2: Development Grants"^"RNA can now be used to safely and selectively treat human diseases. RNA can be used as a template to make a new protein
column3: such as in mRNA vaccines. But RNA can also be used change how coding elements are spliced together and the protein that results from them. This strategy has recently been used to great effect in difficult-to-treat diseases
column4: like muscular dystrophy. We will now apply this same disruptive RNA technology to develop a novel treatment for chronic kidney disease."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022674^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022674"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Development of a Plasmodium vivax multi-analyte lateral flow assay to accelerate malaria elimination
column2: Development Grants"^"To efficiently eliminate Plasmodium vivax (Pv)
column3: malaria control programs require novel
column4: easy-to-use tools to identify and treat people with hidden dormant Pv liver-stage infections. We have developed the first test to meet this requirement: a novel serological test that recognises specific patterns in a person's immune response to malaria. We are now developing a field-deployable rapid diagnostic test to ensure translation of this public health opportunity to accelerate malaria elimination."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022693^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022693"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The development of DMX8.1 as a novel treatment for immunotherapy-refractory cancers
column2: Development Grants"^"Optimal treatment is critical for cancer patient outcome
column3: however
column4: a significant proportion of patients fail to respond and relapse. Using clinically-relevant tumour models
column5: this proposal is aimed at validating the efficacy of a novel drug that can be used either alone or in combination with other therapeutic agents to define the best combination and sequence of treatments to allow immunotherapies to be more effective in more patients."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022723^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022723"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Preclinical Validation of a Targeted Theranostic Agent for MRI Guided Radiotherapy and Radiosensitisation of Aggressive Brain Tumours
column2: Development Grants"^"This project aims to validate preclinically FerroTrace-FAPi
column3: a theranostic agent designed to improve and facilitate image guided radiotherapy. Successful outcomes would enable and improve aggressive image-guided treatment of brain tumours with acceptable neurological toxicity
column4: including in the near future with proton beam radiotherapy. It would also pave the way to rapid commercialisation of FerroTrace-FAPi via the FDA orphan-drug designation pathway."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018644^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018644"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Small Steps for Big Changes: Implementing an Evidence-Based Diabetes Prevention Program into Diverse Urban Communities
column2: International Collaborations"^"Small Steps for Big Changes is an evidence-based type 2 diabetes prevention program. Following initial success
column3: we are now scaling up the program to deliver it in community settings across both Canada and Australia. Our trial will investigate how community-
column4: organisation-
column5: provider-
column6: and patient-level factors contribute to implementation outcomes when organisations deliver the same program in different contexts. We will also examine cost-effectiveness and program impacts on diabetes prevention."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018862^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018862"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Choose To Move Sydney
column2: International Collaborations"^"Physical activity is crucial for health across the lifespan and is key to healthy ageing. Choose To Move (CTM) was developed by researchers in British Columbia
column3: Canada
column4: in collaboration with older adults and community-based organisations and is effective in supporting older people to increase physical activity. This research will adapt CTM to suit the needs of older Arabic speaking people in Sydney
column5: who are particularly inactive and not well supported by existing physical activity programs."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020155^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2020155"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Building CapaCITY/É for Sustainable Transportation
column2: International Collaborations"^"Active and sustainable transport (such as walking and bike riding) are critical to supporting health
column3: mobility and equity outcomes. However
column4: cities globally are struggling to implement infrastructure to enable greater uptake of these modes of transport. Through partnerships with Australian government agencies and Canadian collaborators
column5: we will develop a novel framework that will support governments in successfully implementing interventions to enable active and sustainable transportation."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2023127^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2023127"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Supporting Healthy Lifestyle Choices to Promote Mental Health & Wellbeing of Indigenous Youth Aging-Out-of-Care in Urban Settings
column2: International Collaborations"^"First Nations children and young people comprise one third of children living in out-of-home care and for many the time spent in care undermines their connection to culture and community. Young people transitioning from care are vulnerable and often have limited capacity to connect with their culture and community. This project will apply a strengths-based approach to co-design culturally-grounded programs to support and improve the wellbeing of First Nations youth (12-17 years) in care."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018589^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018589"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Development of Innovative Antimicrobials for Combatting Multidrug-resistant Gram-negative Bacteria: An integrated multi-disciplinary approach
column2: International Collaborations"^"The World Health Organization (WHO) has highlighted antibiotic resistance as a major global health crisis. Gram-negative bacteria top the WHO priority pathogen list due to the lack of therapeutic options
column3: and toxic polymyxins are often the last resort. This project will be the first to integrate cutting-edge computational and experimental approaches to develop novel
column4: safer polymyxins and their inhalation formulations. Our study targets the urgent global medical need for new antibiotics."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018677^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018677"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Gut leak and microbiome contribution to severe dengue disease
column2: International Collaborations"^"Mosquito-borne dengue virus is a major health threat in tropical areas. When some patients are recovering from fever
column3: their condition suddenly deteriorates with life-threatening bleeding and shock. We propose that severe disease is the result of virus-induced damage to the gut
column4: allowing entry of bacterial products into the body. Together with collaborators in Thailand and Japan
column5: we will investigate the impact of gut bacteria on dengue disease and possible probiotic treatments."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018695^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2018695"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Applying novel serological exposure markers to quantify residual malaria transmission in the Philippines
column2: International Collaborations"^"Malaria is an infectious disease that still affects millions of people worldwide
column3: including in the East Asian region. In the Philippines
column4: recent outbreaks of malaria caused by Plasmodium vivax have occurred. Plasmodium vivax is difficult to eliminate due to hidden liver-stage parasites
column5: known as hypnozoites. We will apply our novel surveillance tools to understand how these outbreaks are occurring; to identify the hidden hypnozoite reservoir; and to accelerate malaria elimination."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022885^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022885"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Taking steps against the burden of Parkinson’s disease
column2: International Collaborations"^"Parkinson’s disease (PD) affects over 10 million people worldwide. Unstable gait and falls affect 70% of PD patients. This EU Joint Project investigates the mechanistic changes underpinning successful treadmill intervention that are enhanced by mechanically or virtual-reality triggered gait adaptations. Four clinical centers (Sydney
column3: Tel Aviv
column4: Bolongna and Kiel) will recruit 168 PD patients randomized 1:1 to intervention or control groups. Outcomes will improve fall prevention in people with PD."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022997^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022997"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"Facilitating focused ultrasound-mediated Tau clearance in Alzheimer's disease and other Tauopathies by understanding the underlying autophagic mechanisms
column2: International Collaborations"^"Ultrasound (US) is routinely used for diagnostic imaging
column3: but applicability of this non-invasive technology extends far beyond bio-imaging. We have shown that US clears toxic Tau typical of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). With a team of experts in AD
column4: US technology and multimodal imaging we aim to understand the underlying Tau clearance mechanisms and monitor the process in relation to blood flow. The proposed work constitutes an important step towards developing an US therapy for AD patients."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2023333^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2023333"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"The role of microglia in the effects of environmental enrichment in neurodegenerative disorders
column2: International Collaborations"^"Environmental enrichment (EE) is a powerful preclinical manipulation with remarkable therapeutic promise for neurodegenerative diseases
column3: however its molecular mechanisms remain elusive. Here
column4: we will study the role of inflammatory brain cells in mediating clinical and pathological benefits of EE in models of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and motor neuron disease (MND). Gene targets in microglia mediating benefits of EE will be identified which could be therapeutically exploited in neurodegeneration."^""^""^""^

column1: https://demo.researchdata.ardc.edu.au/view?key=http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022398^"http://purl.org/au-research/grants/nhmrc/2022398"^"activity"^"www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants/research-funding-statistics-and-data"^"grant"^""^""^"It’s time to flourish: Co-designed perinatal and early years care
column2: self-determined by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women
column3: Resulting in policy and practice transformation and Exceptional service (ICARE).
column4: Targeted Call for Research"^"Close the Gap targets and the consistent voices of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people want our babies to be strong and healthy with the best start to life. This begins in pregnancy. This multi-faceted research will provide culturally appropriate and strength-based tools and supports during pregnancy and the early years to empower families. The study will generate new knowledge about empowerment
column5: health system responses and improved data to track and understand the parent’s journey."^""^""^""^
